revision.comment: Removing from [[Category:American women writers]] (parent category) using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Betty Dodson | image = BettyDodson2010.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1929|08|24}} | birth_place = [[Wichita, Kansas]], [[United States|U.S.]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | nationality = American | other_names = | occupation = | known_for = [[Sex-positive feminism]] }} '''Betty Dodson''' (born August 24, 1929) is an American [[sex education|sex educator]]. An artist by training, she exhibited erotic art in New York, before pioneering the [[Sex-positive feminism|pro-sex feminist]] movement, separate from mainstream [[feminism]], which she sees as needlessly political and hostile towards males. Dodson’s workshops and manuals encourage women to masturbate, often in groups. Although bisexual herself, she repudiates the labels that define sexuality.
== Early career == Originally from Kansas, Dodson went to New York City to train as an artist in 1950, and has lived on [[Manhattan]]'s [[Madison Avenue]] since 1962.<ref name="GuardMay14">{{cite news| last = Theobold | first = Stephanie | url = https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2014/may/05/masturbation-secret-to-a-long-life-betty-dodson-self-love|title=Masturbation: the secret to a long life? | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = May 5, 2014 | accessdate = March 7, 2015 }}</ref> In 1959, Dodson married Frederick Stern, an advertising director, with the marriage ending in divorce in 1965.<ref name="GuardMay14"/> Dodson's quest for "sexual self-discovery" began after her divorce.<ref name="GuardMay14"/> Dodson held the first one-woman show of erotic art at the Wickersham Gallery in New York City in 1968. She left the art world to teach sex to women. She is widely known as a pioneer in women's liberation, and to a somewhat lesser extent in men's [[sexual liberation]], having sold more than one million copies of her first book, ''[[Sex for One]]''. Much of her fame has come from her work not only advocating [[masturbation]], but conducting workshops for more than 30 years in which groups of about 10 or more women (and at least once a group of men) would talk, explore their own bodies, and masturbate together. Her website, "Betty Dodson's Genital Gallery," showed many films of masturbation and intercourse, with close-up views of genitals.<ref>[http://www.dodsonandross.com/what-happened-bettys-genital-art-gallery On the reasons why Betty Dodson's Genital Gallery disappeared (Retrieved November 9, 2017)]</ref>
She left behind the traditional feminist movement, because she considered it banal, [[antisexual]] and over-politicized. Dodson considers too much is made of sexual labels and embraces them all by calling herself a heterosexual, bisexual lesbian. She looks forward to the day we can all be just "sexual."<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = We Are All Quite Queer (blog) | url = http://dodsonandross.com/sexfeature/we-are-all-quite-queer | website = Bettydodson.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross | date = June 26, 2005 | access-date = November 17, 2006 }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref> In recent years she has criticized [[Eve Ensler]]'s ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'', which she believes has a negative and restrictive view of sexuality and an anti-male bias.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = Betty's Response to the ''Vagina Monologues'' (blog) | url = http://dodsonandross.com/sexfeature/bettys-response-vagina-monologues | website = Bettydodson.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross | date = March 15, 2001 | accessdate = September 9, 2013 }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref>
Dodson earned a degree from the [[Institute for the Advanced Study of Human Sexuality]] for her research work on sexuality.<ref>{{cite web | title = Betty Dodson author biography | url = http://www.randomhouse.com/author/7172/betty-dodson | website = randomhouse.com | publisher = [[Random House]] | accessdate = April 8, 2012 }}</ref>
== Women's masturbation education == Dodson became active in the [[sex-positive movement]] in the late 1960s.<ref name="barbarajlove2006">{{citation | last = Love | first = Barbara J. | author-link = Barbara Love | contribution = Dodson, Betty Ann | editor-last = Love | editor-first = Barbara J. | editor-link = Barbara Love | title = Feminists who changed America, 1963–1975 |pages=120–121 | publisher = University of Illinois Press | location = Urbana, Illinois | year = 2006 | isbn = 9780252031892 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Dodson used the [[Hitachi Magic Wand]], a powerful main-powered [[vibrator (sex toy)|vibrator]], in demonstrations and instructional classes to instruct women regarding self-pleasure techniques.<ref name="christophertrout">{{cite news|last=Trout|first=Christopher|title=The 46-year-old sex toy Hitachi won't talk about|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/08/27/history-of-the-hitachi-magic-wand/|accessdate= August 30, 2014|work=[[Engadget]]|date= August 27, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140827183517/http://www.engadget.com/2014/08/27/history-of-the-hitachi-magic-wand/|archivedate=27 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="westheimer">{{citation | last = Westheimer | first = Ruth K. | authorlink = Ruth K. Westheimer | contribution = Savouring solo play and fantasy | editor-last = Westheimer | editor-first = Ruth K. | editor-link = Ruth K. Westheimer | title = Sex for dummies | pages = 204–206 | publisher = Wiley | location = Hoboken, New Jersey | year = 2007 | isbn = 9780470045237 }}</ref> She recommended women put a small towel over their sex organs in order to dull the sensation of the vibrator and prolong the pleasurable experience.<ref name="kmkemp2003">{{cite journal|first=K.M.|last=Kemp|journal=[[Marie Claire]]|date=June 2003|page=233|title=25 ways to have your best orgasm ever!|volume=10|issue=6|via=[[InfoTrac]]|publisher=Hearst Communications | url = http://connection.ebscohost.com/c/articles/9810770/25-ways-have-your-best-orgasm-ever | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Her technique became known as the Betty Dodson Method.<ref name="piastruck">{{Cite journal | first1 = Pia | last1 = Struck | last2 = Ventegodt | first2 = Søren | title = Clinical holistic medicine: teaching orgasm for females with chronic anorgasmia using the Betty Dodson Method | journal = [[The Scientific World Journal]] | volume = 8 | issue = | pages = 883–895 | publisher = [[Hindawi Publishing Corporation]] | doi = 10.1100/tsw.2008.116 | date = 2008 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1100/tsw.2008.116 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Her sessions were known as Bodysex workshops and featured 15 naked women in supine position, each using a Magic Wand simultaneously to aid in masturbation.<ref name="winks1997">{{citation | last1 = Winks | first1 = Cathy | last2 = Semans | first2 = Anne | contribution = ''Profiles in pleasure: Betty Dodson'' | Vibrators and partners | editor-last1 = Winks | editor-first1 = Cathy | editor-last2 = Semans | editor-first2 = Anne | title = [[The Good Vibrations Guide to Sex|The new good vibrations guide to sex]] | pages = 102 & 154 | publisher = Cleis Press | location = Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania | year = 1997 | isbn = 9781573440691 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> She provided a Magic Wand to each woman for these two-hour masturbation sessions.<ref name="dodson1996">{{citation | last = Dodson | first = Betty | contribution = Making love alone | editor-last = Dodson | editor-first = Betty | title = Sex for one: the joy of selfloving | page = 154 | publisher = Crown Trade Paperbacks | location = New York | year = 1996 | isbn = 9780517886076 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Dodson taught thousands of women to achieve orgasm using this technique.<ref name="winks1997" />
== Later career == Dodson published a memoir, ''Sex by Design'', in 2010.<ref name="GuardMay14"/>
In 2014, she expressed that she considers herself a [[fourth-wave feminist]], stating that the previous waves of feminist were banal and anti-sexual, which is why she has chosen to look at a new stance of feminism, fourth wave feminism. In 2014, Dodson worked with women to discover their sexual desires through masturbation. Dodson says her work has gained a fresh lease of life with a new audience of young, successful women who have never had an orgasm. This includes fourth-wave feminists – those rejecting the anti-pleasure stance they believe [[third-wave feminism|third-wave feminists]] stand for.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Smith | first = Lydia | title = Betty Dodson and fourth-wave feminism: masturbation is key to longer life | url = http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/betty-dodson-fourth-wave-feminism-masturbation-key-longer-life-1447536 | work = [[International Business Times]] | date = May 7, 2014 |access-date = May 12, 2014 }}</ref>
Dodson maintains a private practice in New York City and has an active website.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = Home page | url = http://dodsonandross.com | website = dodsonandross.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross | access-date = December 12, 2013 }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref> In an article on her website about hands-on sex therapy, she explains her choice against pursuing a degree in [[psychology]] and licensing as a therapist since it would have prevented her from continuing with the types of sex workshops and counseling for women that she had been doing for decades.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = Ask Dr. Betty – Sex Coaching | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070407222128/http://www.bettydodson.com/sexcoachinginfo.htm | archive-date = April 7, 2007 | url = http://www.bettydodson.com/sexcoachinginfo.htm | website = bettydodson.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross | access-date = December 12, 2013 }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref> She is available for group and solo Bodysex workshops and private individual and couples coaching.<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = Bodysex for one and for groups | url = http://dodsonandross.com/private-session-dr-betty-dodson | website = dodsonandross.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref>
== Publication and other works== Dodson's books include ''Liberating Masturbation'', ''Sex for One: The Joy of Self-Loving'' and ''Orgasms for Two: the Joy of Partnersex''. She also produced four videos: ''Selfloving: Portrait of a Sexual Seminar'', ''Celebrating Orgasm: Women's Private Selfloving Sessions'', ''Viva la Vulva: Women's Sex Organs Revealed'' and ''The Orgasm Doctor: Two Private Hands-on Sex Coaching Sessions''.
In 2006, [[:es:Carlin Ross|Carlin Ross]], a former [[corporate lawyer]], met Betty Dodson for an interview and became her business partner.<ref name="GuardMay14"/> They created an online sexuality portal<ref>{{cite web | last = Dodson | first = Betty | title = Home page | url = http://dodsonandross.com | website = dodsonandross.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross | access-date = December 4, 2013 }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref> for women under the brand Dodson and Ross. Together, they launched an online video series ''[[Basic Sex Skills: The New Porn]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last1 = Dodson | first1 = Betty | last2 = Ross | first2 = Carlin | title = About us | url = https://dodsonandross.com/about-u | website = dodsonandross.com | publisher = Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross }} {{Self published inline|date = February 2017|certain = yes}}</ref>
== Media appearances == Dodson appeared in a Season 4 episode of [[Penn & Teller]]'s ''[[Penn & Teller: Bullshit!|Bullshit!]]'' that dealt with [[Sexual abstinence|abstinence]].<ref>{{Cite episode | title = Abstinence | episode-link = List of Penn & Teller: Bullshit! episodes#Season 4 (2006) | url = http://www.sho.com/penn-and-teller-bullshit/season/4/episode/6 | series = Penn & Teller: Bullshit! | series-link = Penn & Teller: Bullshit! | first1 = Penn (co-host) | last1 = Jillette | last2 = Teller (co-host) | first3 = Betty (guest) | last3 = Dodson | author-link1 = Penn Jillette | author-link2 = Teller (magician) | network = [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] | station = [[CBS Corporation|CBS]] | date = June 5, 2006 | season = 4 |number= 10 }}</ref> She was also on ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'', and has appeared in numerous sex documentaries.
==Bibliography== *''Liberating Masturbation'' (1974) *''Sex for One: The Joy of Selfloving'' (1987) *''Orgasms for Two: the Joy of Partnersex'' (2002) *''My Romantic Love Wars'' (2010) *''Learn How to Orgasm'' (edited by Carlin Ross, 2011) *''Learn to Orgasm in 4 Acts'' (2013)
;By others *''[[Cunt: A Declaration of Independence]]'' by Inga Muscio (Foreword by Betty Dodson, 1998)
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://dodsonandross.com Betty Dodson with Carlin Ross. Better Orgasms. Better World.] *[http://dodsonandross.com/essay/bettys-response-vagina-monologues Dodson's critique of ''The Vagina Monologues''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060101043224/http://www.bettydodson.com/vaginano.htm |date=January 1, 2006 }} *[http://www.personallifemedia.com/podcasts/minds-of-men/episode002-betty-dodson-phd.html Audio Interview with Betty Dodson on "Liberating Masturbation" – includes transcript] *[http://www.dodsonandross.com/about Dodson & Ross About Us] *[http://planetwaves.net/pagetwo/2009/08/24/happy-80th-birthday-betty-dodson/ Biographical tribute to Betty on her 80th birthday by her student Eric Francis]

page.title: Catholic Church sexual abuse cases in New Zealand

revision.text:
There have been a number of [[Catholic sex abuse cases]] in [[Roman Catholicism in New Zealand|New Zealand]], linked to [[List of Catholic schools in New Zealand|Catholic schools]]. __NOTOC__
==Cases== The first recorded case was in 1900. Allegations of cruelty toward children residing at the [[Stoke Industrial School]] (also known as St Mary's Orphanage) instigated a Royal Commission and the eventual prosecution of two Marist Brothers. Edouard Forrier (Brother Wybertus) was charged with five counts of common assault. They were also charged with five counts of indecent assault of which they were acquitted. The alleged incidents occurred between September 5, 1893 and June 1, 1897.<ref>[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZH19000921.2.57&e=-------10--1----0Colonist-- The Stoke School Scandal], ''New Zealand Herald'', Vol. XXXVII, Issue 11483, 21 Sept. 1900, 6.</ref>
Marist Father Alan Woodcock abused children at [[St John's College, Hastings|St John's College]] in [[Hastings]], [[St. Patrick's College, Silverstream|St Patrick's College]] in [[Upper Hutt]], [[Highden]] in the [[Manawatu]] and [[Futuna (retreat)|Futuna]] in [[Wellington]]. After he left the [[Marist Priesthood]] and left New Zealand to live in England, he was extradited back to New Zealand and convicted of 21 sex offences committed between 1978 and 1987. The abuse continued despite the knowledge of Father Michael Curtain and Father Fred Bliss.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3574937 |title=Police may go after the clergymen who hid abuse |work=nzherald.co.nz |year=2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref> Tracking him down abroad was done with the assistance of the [[Sisters of St Joseph of Nazareth]].<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3567930 |title=Sex abuser's sisters bring him home to face justice |work=nzherald.co.nz |year=2012 |quote=Sisters of St Joseph of Nazareth |accessdate=22 April 2012 |first=Eugene |last=Bingham}}</ref>
John Louis Stevenson (known as Brother Bernard) and Brother Andrew Cody of the [[Hato Paora College|Hato Paora Māori Boys school]] in [[Feilding]] were convicted of sexual offenses and jailed.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10361156 |title=Jailed churchman was sexually abused as child |work=nzherald.co.nz |year=2012 |accessdate=22 April 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/feilding/news/article.cfm?l_id=200&objectid=10342691 | work=The New Zealand Herald | title=Catholic brother sent to jail for abusing boys | date=August 27, 2005}}</ref>
In 2011 a staff member of [[St Bede's College, Christchurch]] admitted to being a sex offender before he was employed at that college, but was allowed to remain as a teacher.<ref>'[https://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/teacher-stayed-working-even-after-admitting-abuse Teacher stayed working even after admitting abuse]' on ''[[Otago Daily Times]]'' website, 7 September 2018, viewed 19 September 2018</ref> In 2018, abuse victim advocates called for the resignation of the school's rector for continuing the staff member's employment.<ref>'[https://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/school-stays-silent-amid-calls-resignation School stays silent amid calls for resignation]' on ''[[Otago Daily Times]]'' website, 19 September 2018, viewed 19 September 2018</ref>
In 2017 and 2018, the issue was raised of [[Magnus Murray (Catholic priest)|Magnus Murray]], a Catholic priest, who taught at [[Kavanagh College#Christian Brothers School (St Paul's High School) (1876–1989)|St Paul's College, Dunedin]], until 1972 and was later convicted of child sexual abuse.<ref name="remains">[https://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/paedophile-remains-priest 'Paedophile remains a priest'] on''[[Otago Daily Times]]'' website dated 2017-08-11, viewed 10 September 2018</ref> Allegations were also made against former Christian Brothers Junior School principal, Desmond Fay.<ref name="scale">[https://www.odt.co.nz/news/dunedin/scale-abuse-suffering-revealed 'Scale of abuse revealed'] on ''[[Otago Daily Times]]'' website, dated 2018-09-07, viewed 2018-09-10</ref> [[Michael Dooley]], Bishop of Dunedin, acknowledged the offences of Murray and Fay and apologised for the "suffering endured by victims and their families".<ref name="dooleyletter">Letter dated 22 August 2018 by Bishop Michael Dooley, published on [http://cdd.org.nz Catholic Diocese of Dunedin] website; [https://web.archive.org/web/20180910033852/https://static1.squarespace.com/static/51dbe649e4b09506a9c7266f/t/5b7e376c0e2e7270a52cd453/1534998400119/Bishop+Michael%27s+letter.jpg?format=750w archived] on [[Internet Archive]] on 2018-09-10.</ref>
==Marylands School== {{Main|Sexual abuse scandal at Marylands School, Christchurch}} [[Marylands School]], which was operated by the [[Brothers Hospitallers of St. John of God]], a Catholic religious order in [[Christchurch]], was the centre of a number of sex abuse cases. By 2006, the [[Australasia]]n branch of the St John of God order had paid out $5.1 million to survivors who had been sexually abused at the school.<ref name="Henzell">{{cite news | last = Henzell| first = John| coauthors = | title = Trial attempt to regain faith | work = | pages = 1| publisher = [[The Press]]| date = 2006-03-17}}</ref> A nonprofit trust, the Survivors of Sex Abuse Trust, worked with many of the victims. Over 120 complaints were made in regard to sexual and physical abuse alleged to have occurred at the school.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fresh allegations against order|last=Martin|first=Yvonne|date=2007-06-21|publisher=The Press}}</ref> Many of the offences were committed in the 1970s.
==See also== * [[Catholic sexual abuse cases in Australia]] * [[Roman Catholic sex abuse cases by country]] * [[Roman Catholicism in New Zealand]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[http://survivor.org.nz/ Male Survivors of Sexual Abuse Trust] - New Zealand support group * {{cite web | url=http://paulburns.site50.net/NZ_Clerical_Abuse.html | title=Sexual Abuse by New Zealand Clergy | publisher=Site 50 | date=Feb 24, 2014 | accessdate=December 6, 2014 | author=Burns, Paul}}
{{Sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Church}}

{{Multiple issues| {{third-party|date=August 2013}} {{One source|date=March 2017}} }} The '''Certified Wireless Network Administrator''' (CWNA) is a foundation level certification from the [[CWNP]] that measures the ability to administer any [[wireless LAN]].<ref name="cwnp.com">{{citeweb|title=Preparation Guide for Exam PW0-100 - Wireless LAN Administration|url=http://www.cwnp.com/exams/pw0100.html|publisher=CWNP|accessdate=2008-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516190047/http://www.cwnp.com/exams/pw0100.html|archivedate=2008-05-16|df=}}</ref> A wide range of topics focusing on the [[802.11]] wireless LAN technology are covered in the coursework and exam, which is vendor neutral.<ref>{{citeweb|title=CWNA Wireless LAN Administration Certification|url=http://www.sybex.com/WileyCDA/Section/id-292165.html|publisher=sybex.com|accessdate=2008-02-16}}</ref>
== Certification track == The Certified Wireless Network Administrator (CWNA) is a foundation level wireless certification for the Certified Wireless Network Professional (CWNP) program. The CWNP next offers three professional level certifications: Certified Wireless Security Professional (CWSP), Certified Wireless Analysis Professional (CWAP) and Certified Wireless Design Professional (CWDP). A candidate can only achieve the expert level [[CWNE]] certification after earning the CWNA, CWSP, CWAP and CWDP certifications. A candidate no longer has to pass an exam for the expert level Certified Wireless Network Expert (CWNE) certification. In addition to passing the CWNA, CWSP, CWAP and CWDP a candidate must also provide: 3 professional endorsements, 3 years of documented enterprise [[Wi-Fi]] experience, 2 other current valid networking certifications and documentation of 3 enterprise Wi-Fi projects the candidate has participated in or led.<ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/cwna/</ref><ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/cwsp/</ref><ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/cwap/</ref><ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/cwdp/</ref><ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/cwne/</ref>
== CWNA requirements == The main subject areas covered by the CWNA are as follows:<ref name="cwnp.com" /> *Radio Technologies *Antenna Concepts *Wireless LAN hardware and software *Network Design Installation and Management *Wireless Standards and Organization *Owning One's Performance *Adding Value at Every Turn *802.11 Network Architecture *Wireless LAN Security *Promoting Epic Back Thickness *Troubleshooting *How to perform site surveys
These subjects are covered at an introductory level in the CWNA coursework and examination. The other certifications specialize in one or more of these subjects.
== Recertification == The CWNA certification is valid for three years.<ref name=recert>{{citeweb|title=How to Recertify|url=http://www.cwnp.com/exams/recert_policy.html|publisher=CWNP|accessdate=2008-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516222116/http://www.cwnp.com/exams/recert_policy.html|archivedate=2008-05-16|df=}}</ref> The certification may be renewed by retaking the CWNA exam or by passing one of the 3 professional level certification exams (CWSP, CWAP or CWDP).<ref>http://www.cwnp.com/certifications/exams/recertification/</ref>
==See also== *[[Professional certification (Computer technology)]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Official website|www.cwnp.com}} Sybex Publishing Study Guide: https://www.wiley.com/go/cwnasg [[Category:Wireless networking]] [[Category:Information technology qualifications]]

page.title: Charles A. Lindbergh Chair in Aerospace History

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
The '''Charles A. Lindbergh Chair in Aerospace History''', also known as the '''Lindbergh Chair''', is a one-year senior fellowship hosted by the U.S. [[National Air and Space Museum]] (NASM), to assist a scholar in the research and composition of a book about aerospace history. Named for the famous aviator [[Charles Lindbergh]], the position is competitive: one experienced scholar is selected each year from multiple applicants worldwide. Up to $100,000 is granted to the winner.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/getinvolved/fellow/lindfellow.cfm |title=Charles A. Lindbergh Chair in Aerospace History |work=Get Involved: Internships & Fellowships |publisher=[[National Air and Space Museum]] |accessdate=May 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606130914/http://www.nasm.si.edu/getinvolved/fellow/lindfellow.cfm |archivedate=June 6, 2011 |df= }} The Lindbergh Chair is one of four research fellowships administered by NASM within the [[Smithsonian Institution]]: the others are the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Fellowship, the [[A. Verville Fellowship]], and the Postdoctoral Earth and Planetary Sciences Fellowship.{{cite web|url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/getinvolved/fellow/index.cfm |title=National Air and Space Museum Research Fellowships |work=Get Involved: Internships & Fellowships |publisher=[[National Air and Space Museum]] |accessdate=May 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410065957/http://www.nasm.si.edu/getinvolved/fellow/index.cfm |archivedate=April 10, 2011 |df= }} Announced in 1977 at the 50th anniversary of Lindbergh's famous solo flight,{{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/events/pressroom/presskits/museumkit/siflight.cfm |title=National Air and Space Museum Press Kit: The Smithsonian and Flight |work=Press Room |publisher=National Air and Space Museum |accessdate=May 26, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120306040520/http://www.nasm.si.edu/events/pressroom/presskits/museumkit/siflight.cfm |archivedate=March 6, 2012 |df= }} 1978 was the first year that the Lindbergh Chair was occupied—British aviation historian [[Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith]] was selected as the first recipient.{{citation |url=http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/periods_styles/features/history/staff_obituaries/photography/gibbs_smith/index.html |title=Charles Harvard Gibbs-Smith |work=Staff Obituaries |publisher=Victoria and Albert Museum |quote=Reproduced with kind permission of The Times ©Times Newspapers Limited |accessdate=May 26, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115163356/http://www.vam.ac.uk/collections/periods_styles/features/history/staff_obituaries/photography/gibbs_smith/index.html# |archive-date=2011-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Each Lindbergh Chair application is judged relative to the suitability of its proposal, the scholarly record of the applicant, the availability of relevant museum staff advisors knowledgeable on the proposed topic, whether the NASM can provide the specific resources, and the applicability of the proposal to NASM's work-in-progress series. The winner is expected to reside in the [[Washington, DC]], area for nine months to a year, the academic year generally starting in September and ending by the following August. He or she is also expected to take part in discussions with museum staff and to attend professional seminars and colloquia.{{cite web |url=http://www.nasm.si.edu/getinvolved/fellow/fellowapp_instructions.pdf |title=General Instructions for Guggenheim, Verville, and Lindbergh Fellowship Applicants |work=Get Involved: Internships & Fellowships |publisher=[[National Air and Space Museum]] |accessdate=May 26, 2011}} Along with access to primary research materials, the winner is given the use of an office, a phone and a computer. ==Past winners== {| class="sortable wikitable" |- ! style="background:#ccf; width=9%" | Year ! style="background:#ccf; width=44%" | Awardee ! style="background:#ccf; width=12%" | Topic ! style="background:#ccf; width=35%" | Published result |- style="background:#fffff6" | align="center" | 1978

{{more citations needed|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox scientist | name = David A. Freedman | image = David A Freedman (statistician) 1984.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Freedman in 1984 | birth_date = {{birth date |1938|3|5|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada | death_date = {{death date and age |2008|10|17 |1938|3|5 |df=y}} | death_place = [[Berkeley, California]] | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | fields = [[Statistics]] | workplaces = [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] | alma_mater = [[Princeton University]]
[[McGill University]] | doctoral_advisor = [[William Feller]] | doctoral_students = | known_for = | awards = }} '''David Amiel Freedman''' (5 March 1938 – 17 October 2008) was Professor of Statistics at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. He was a distinguished mathematical statistician whose wide-ranging research included the analysis of [[martingale (probability theory)|martingale]] inequalities, [[Markov process]]es, [[de Finetti's theorem]], consistency of [[Bayes estimator]]s, [[sampling (statistics)|sampling]], the [[Bootstrapping (statistics)|bootstrap]], and procedures for testing and evaluating models. He published extensively on methods for [[causal inference]] and the behavior of standard statistical models under non-standard conditions – for example, how [[regression model]]s behave when fitted to data from [[randomized experiment]]s. Freedman also wrote widely on the application—and misapplication—of statistics in the social sciences, including [[epidemiology]], [[public policy]], and [[law]]. == Biography and awards == Freedman was a fellow of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] and the [[American Statistical Association]] and an elected fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. He won the 2003 [[John J. Carty Award for the Advancement of Science]] from the [[United States National Academy of Sciences|National Academy of Sciences]] "for his profound contributions to the theory and practice of statistics, including rigorous foundations for Bayesian inference and trenchant analysis of census adjustment."{{cite web|title=John J. Carty Award for the Advancement of Science|url=http://www.nasonline.org/programs/awards/john-j-carty-award.html|publisher=National Academy of Sciences|accessdate=12 January 2016}} He was a Fellow at the [[Miller Institute for Basic Research in Science]] in 1990, an [[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation]] Fellow in 1964–66, and a [[Canada Council]] Fellow at [[Imperial College London]] in 1960–61. Freedman was born in [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, on 5 March 1938. He received a B.Sc. from [[McGill University]] in 1958 and a M.A. and a Ph.D. from [[Princeton University]] in 1959 and 1960, respectively. He joined the [[University of California, Berkeley]] Department of Statistics in 1961 as a lecturer and was appointed to the research faculty in 1962. He remained at Berkeley his entire career. He started his professional life as a probabilist and mathematical statistician with Bayesian leanings but became one of the world's leading applied statisticians and a circumspect frequentist. Freedman was a consulting or testifying expert on statistics in disputes involving [[employment discrimination]], fair loan practices, [[voting rights]], duplicate signatures on petitions, railroad taxation, [[ecological inference]], flight patterns of [[golf ball]]s, [[price scanner]] errors, [[Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy]] (Mad Cow disease), and sampling. He consulted for the [[Bank of Canada]], the [[Carnegie Commission]], the [[San Francisco|City of San Francisco]], the [[County of Los Angeles]], and the [[Federal Reserve]], as well as the U.S. departments of energy, treasury, justice, and commerce. Freedman and his colleague Kenneth Wachter testified to the [[United States Congress]] and the courts against adjusting the 1980 and 1990 [[census]]es using estimates of differential undercounts. A 1990 lawsuit that sought to compel the [[United States Department of Commerce]] to adjust the census was heard on appeal by the [[U.S. Supreme Court]], which ruled unanimously in favor of the Commerce Department and Freedman and Wachter's analysis. With David Kaye, Freedman wrote a widely used primer on statistics for lawyers and judges published by the [[Federal Judicial Center]], the education and research agency for the [[United States federal courts]]. In addition to his work in [[forensic statistics]], Freedman had a broad impact on the application of statistics to important medical, social, and public policy issues, such as [[clinical trial]]s, [[epidemiology]], [[economic models]], and the interpretation of [[scientific experiment]]s and [[observational studies]]. In his applied work, Freedman emphasized exposing and checking the assumptions that underlie standard methods, as well as understanding how those methods behave when the assumptions are false. He characterized circumstances in which the methods continue to perform well, and those where they break down—regardless of the quality of the data. Two of his earlier results (1963 and 1965) investigate whether or not and under what circumstances a Bayesian learning approach is consistent, i.e. when does the prior converge to the true probability distribution given sufficiently many observed data. In particular the 1965 paper with the innocent title "On the asymptotic behaviour of Bayes estimates in the discrete case II" finds the rather disappointing answer that when sampling from a countably infinite population the [[Bayesian inference|Bayesian procedure]] fails almost everywhere, i.e. one does not obtain the true distribution asymptotically. This situation is quite different from the finite case when the (discrete) random variable takes only finite many values and the Bayesian method is consistent in agreement with earlier findings of Doob (1948). Freedman was the author or co-author of 200 articles, 20 technical reports and six books, including a highly innovative and influential introductory statistics textbook, ''Statistics'' (2007), with Robert Pisani and Roger Purves, which has gone through four editions. The late [[Amos Tversky]] of [[Stanford University]] observed that "This is a great book. It is the best introduction to how to think about statistical issues...." It has a "wealth of real-world examples that illuminate principles and applications....a classic." Freedman's ''Statistical Models: Theory and Practice'' (2005) is an advanced text on statistical modeling that likewise achieves a remarkable integration between extensive examples and statistical theory. Landmark articles by Freedman include "Statistical Models and Shoe Leather" (1991), "What is the Chance of an Earthquake?" (2003), "Methods for Census 2000 and Statistical Adjustments" (2007), and "On Types of Scientific Enquiry: The Role of Qualitative Reasoning" (2008). == Bibliography == * David A. Freedman (1963), "On the asymptotic behaviour of Bayes estimates in the discrete case I". ''The Annals of Mathematical Statistics'', vol. 34, pp. 1386–1403. * David A. Freedman (1965), "On the asymptotic behaviour of Bayes estimates in the discrete case II". ''The Annals of Mathematical Statistics'', vol. 36, pp. 454–456. * {{Cite book |last1 = Freedman | first1 = David|| last2 = Pisani | first2 = Robert | last3 = Purves | first3 = Roger | title = Statistics | url=http://www.wwnorton.com/college/titles/math/stat4/comment.htm|place = [[New York City|New York]] | publisher = [[W. W. Norton & Company|Norton]] | year = 2007 | edition = 4th | isbn = 0-393-92972-8|ref=harv}} * {{cite book|first=David A.|last=Freedman||title=Statistical models: Theory and practice|publisher=Cambridge University Press|url=http://www.cambridge.org/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521671057|ref=harv|year=2005|edition=first}} * {{cite book|first=David A.|last=Freedman||title=Statistical models and causal inferences: A dialogue with the social sciences|year=2010|editor1-first=David|editor1-last=Collier|editor2-first=Jasjeet S.|editor2-last=Sekhon|editor3-first=Philip B.|editor3-last=Stark|publisher=Cambridge University Press|id=This includes the following reprinted papers, some of which have changes|ref=harv}} ** "Statistical Models and Shoe Leather" (1991). ''Sociological Methodology'', vol. 21, pp. 291–313. ** "What is the Chance of an Earthquake?" (2003). With Philip B. Stark. ''Earthquake Science and Seismic Risk Reduction'', NATO Science Series IV: Earth and Environmental Sciences, vol. 32, pp. 201–13.1- [https://web.archive.org/web/20130221102922/http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~stark/Preprints/611.pdf (preprint)] ** "Methods for Census 2000 and Statistical Adjustments" (2007). With Kenneth Wachter. ''Social Science Methodology'', Sage, pp. 232–45. ** "On Types of Scientific Enquiry: The Role of Qualitative Reasoning" (2008). ''Oxford Handbook of Political Methodology'', Oxford University Press. ''The American Statistician'' (2008) 62: 110–119. == See also == * [[Freedman–Diaconis rule]] * [[Freedman's paradox]] == References == {{Reflist}} * ''Reminiscences of a Statistician: The Company I Kept'' (Springer, 2008) [https://www.springer.com/statistics/book/978-0-387-71596-4] * ''Statistics'' 4th edition, by Freedman, Pisani and Purves (Norton, 2007) [http://www.wwnorton.com/college/titles/math/stat4/] * ''Statistical Models: Theory and Practice'' by Freedman (Cambridge, 2005) [http://www.cambridge.org/us/catalogue/catalogue.asp?isbn=9780521671057] == External links == * [https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~freedman/ Personal website] * [https://www.berkeley.edu/news/media/releases/2008/10/20_freedman.shtml University of California, Berkeley, Obituary] * [https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~stark/Preprints/dafObituary.htm Obituary for the Institute of Mathematical Statistics] {{Statistics}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Freedman, David A.}} [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Survey methodologists]] [[Category:Statistics educators]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:Canadian statisticians]] [[Category:American social scientists]] [[Category:University of California, Berkeley faculty]] [[Category:Princeton University alumni]] [[Category:McGill University alumni]] [[Category:People from Montreal]] [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2008 deaths]] [[Category:Recipients of awards from the United States National Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:Probability theorists]] [[Category:Fellows of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]

'''DevCodeCamp''' is a [[coding bootcamp]] based in [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2018/nov/19/the-college-debt-crisis-calls-for-new-education-so/|title=Advancing workforce development programs|date=19 November 2018|publisher=The Washington Times|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> with an additional campus location in [[Madison, Wisconsin|Madison]]. DevCodeCamp offers 12-week<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/money/business/onramp/2017/08/21/milwaukee-coding-school-launching-evening-boot-camp/585950001/|title=Milwaukee coding school launching evening boot camp|date=21 August 2017|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> immersive and 20-week part time bootcamps for [[software development]].
== About == DevCodeCamp was founded in 2015<ref name="Inside">{{cite web|url=https://www.biztimes.com/2017/ideas/economic-development/inside-ward4-devcodecamp-has-been-pumping-out-coders/|title=Inside Ward4, devCodeCamp has been pumping out coders|date=6 March 2017|publisher=BizTimes|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> and was the first coding bootcamp in Wisconsin.<ref name="Milwaukee">{{cite web|url=http://archive.jsonline.com/business/milwaukee-computer-coding-school-expands-as-employers-show-interest-b99564255z1-323170881.html/|title=Milwaukee computer coding school expands as employers show interest|date=27 August 2015|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> The school's headquarters is based in the [[Ward 4 (Milwaukee, WI startup accelerator space)|Ward4 building]] in Milwaukee. Classes can also be taken in Madison. The full time bootcamp is completed within 12 weeks<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.jsonline.com/business/coding-school-teaches-the-languages-of-computers-b99544396z1-318732001.html|title=Coding school teaches the languages of computers|date=27 July 2015|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> and the part time bootcamp within 20 weeks. Once students complete the bootcamp they receive [[interview]] and resume [[training]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tmj4.com/news/special-assignments/devcodecamp-shaking-up-traditional-4-year-degree|title=New Milwaukee boot camp 'devCodeCamp' shaking up traditional 4-year degree|date=|publisher=tmj4.com|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> Furthermore, DevCodeCamp offers free housing in apartments right above the school.<ref name="Coding">{{cite web|url=https://www.insidesources.com/coding-bootcamps-help-americans-fill-21st-century-jobs/|title=Coding Bootcamps Help Americans Fill 21st Century Jobs|date=2018-10-25|publisher=InsideSources|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref>
Since fall 2017, benefits provided by the [[Forever GI Bill]] for [[veterans]] also cover tuition for DevCodeCamp.<ref name="enlist">{{cite web|url=https://www.jsonline.com/story/money/business/2018/03/23/coding-boot-camp-helps-veterans-civilian-software-developer/449744002/|title=Ex-soldiers enlist in 'boot camp' again - this time, to learn software coding|date=23 March 2018|publisher=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref>
By March 2017, more than 100 students had graduated from DevCodeCamp.<ref name="Inside" /> Their average starting salary has been $50,000 per year.<ref name="Coding" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://townhall.com/columnists/jessegrady/2018/10/31/trump-administration-leading-the-way-on-skillsbased-education-options-n2533672|title=Trump Administration Leading the Way on Skills-based Education Options|date=2018-10-31|publisher=Townhall|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref> Graduates have been hired by [[Rockwell Automation]], [[Land's End]], [[Milwaukee Brewers]], [[U.S. Bancorp|U.S. Bank]],<ref name="enlist" /> [[Zywave]],<ref name="Milwaukee" /> and [[Northwestern Mutual]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://xconomy.com/wisconsin/2018/03/28/foxconn-cuna-devcodecamp-more-this-weeks-wisconsin-watchlist/|title=Foxconn, CUNA, DevCodeCamp & More: This Week’s Wisconsin Watchlist|date=28 March 2018|publisher=xconomy|accessdate=28 November 2018}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [https://devcodecamp.com/ Official Website]

revision.text:
[[File:Asmara, university training center.JPG|thumb|right|500px|Asmara, university training center]]
'''Education in [[Eritrea]]''' is officially [[compulsory education|compulsory]] between 7 and 16 years of age.<ref name=cp>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Eritrea.pdf Eritrea country profile]. [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (September 2005). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref> Important goals of [[Eritrea]]'s educational policy are to provide basic education in each of Eritrea's mother tongues<ref>{{cite journal|last=Asfaha|first=Yonas Mesfun|author2=Jeanne Kurvers |author3=Sjaak Kroon |title=Literacy use and instruction in multilingual Eritrea|journal=Leeds African Studies Bulletin|year=2006}}</ref> as well as to produce a society that is equipped with the necessary skills to function with a culture of self-reliance in the modern economy.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Eritrea.pdf |title=Eritrea |date=September 2010 |work=World Data on Education |publisher=United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> The education infrastructure is currently inadequate to meet these needs.<ref name=cp/>
==History==
{{Quote|''The first schools in Ertrea were those of the catholic missionaries, but in 1902 were officially created by the Italian government the first two elementary schools in Italian Eritrea, with two teachers from Italy: the first and main in Asmara and the second in Cheren.<ref>[http://www.scuoleasmara.it/scuola/scuola-coloniale.html Scuola coloniale eritrea (in Italian)]</ref> During colonial times most of the students were Italians, but after WW2 the number of Eritrean students has increased: in 1956 they were 17% of the students (while the Italians were 83%), while in 2015 they were nearly all. The highest-level institution (in the 1930s) was the Italian Lyceum "Ferdinando Martini" in Eritrea's capital, that was founded in 1926.''B. D'Ambrosio}}
Initially there were only a few religious schools in [[Italian Eritrea|Eritrea]], but with the Italian governments were started the first school systems in Eritrea mainly during the late 1930s (when was established the [[Eritrea Governorate]]). In 1940 Dr. [[Vincenzo Di Meglio]] promoted the creation of the "School of Medicine" in Asmara (the first university institution in Eritrea, located initially in the [[Liceo Sperimentale "G. Marconi"|Liceo Martini]]), under the direction of Prof. Ferro Luzzi<ref>[http://www.ilcornodafrica.it/st-nik%20scuola.pdf Nicky Di Paolo: "La Scuola di Medicina di Asmara" (in Italian)]</ref>.
{{Quote|''In 1940 a group of Italian doctors under the leadership of Dr. Vincenzo Di Meglio promoted the creation of university studies in Asmara and in 1941 they created the "Scuola di Medicina" (using a section of the Liceo Martini), linked to the Asmara Hospital (then named "Regina Elena"). It was the first university institution of Eritrea and aimed at the preparation of students for the Faculty of Medicine in the University of Rome.''Silvia Nocchi}}
After [[WW2]] was created the [[University of Asmara|first university in Asmara]]. This university was founded in 1958, albeit by a different name as the ''Collegio Cattolico della Santa Famiglia'' while ruled by the Italian religious organization called 'Piae Madres Nigritiae' ("Comboni Sisters"): successively, in 1964 the university had been renamed as "University of Asmara".
In the 1990s the independent Eritrea started a program to bring literacy to all children in Eritrea. Since then the school system has reached nearly 90% of young [[Eritreans]].
==Levels education== [[Image:Eritrea 13.jpg|thumb|Pupils in uniform]] There are five levels of education in Eritrea, pre-primary, primary, middle, secondary and tertiary. There are nearly 238,000 students in the primary, middle, and secondary levels of education. There are approximately 824 schools<ref>{{cite book | year = 2005|url=http://www1.chr.up.ac.za/chr_old/indigenous/documents/Eritrea/Report/Base%20line%20study%20on%20Livelihood%20Systems%20in%20Eritrea.pdf | title = Baseline Study on Livelihood Systems in Eritrea | publisher = National Food Information System of Eritrea }} </ref> in Eritrea and two universities, [[University of Asmara]] (UoA) and the [[Eritrea Institute of Technology]] (EIST), as well as several smaller colleges and technical schools.
Current centers of tertiary education in Eritrea include, the College of Marine Biology, the College of Agriculture, the College of Arts and Social Sciences, the College of Business and Economics, the College of Nursing and Health Technology, as well as EIST and the UoA.There are some big primary and middle schools like Mai-Tesfa, Awet and Model<ref name="college">{{cite web | last = Habtetsion | first = Efrem | title = On Developing Higher Level of Education | date = 2006-08-03 | url = http://www.shaebia.org/artman/publish/article_4617.html | accessdate = 2006-08-03 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060830220343/http://www.shaebia.org/artman/publish/article_4617.html <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2006-08-30}}</ref>
The education system in Eritrea is also designed to promote private sector schooling, equal access for all groups (i.e. prevent gender discrimination, prevent ethnic discrimination, prevent class discrimination, etc.) and promote continuing education through formal and informal systems.
Barriers to education in Eritrea include traditional taboos, school fees (for registration and materials), and the cost barriers of low-income households.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Kifle | first = Temesgen|editor=Andreas Knorr |editor2=Alfons Lemper |editor3=Axel Sell |editor4=Karl Wohlmuth |url=http://www.iwim.uni-bremen.de/publikationen/pdf/b079.pdf | title = Educational Gender Gap in Eritrea|publisher=Institute for World Economics and International Management|journal=Berichte aus dem Weltwirtschaftlichen Colloquium der Universität Bremen|volume= 78|date= April 2002}} </ref>
==Statistics==
Statistics suggest that between 39 and 57 percent of school-aged children attend [[primary school]] and 21 percent attend secondary school.<ref name=cp/> Student-teacher ratios are high: 45 to 1 at the elementary level and 54 to 1 at the secondary level.<ref name=cp/> There are an average 63 students per classroom at the elementary level and 97 per classroom at the secondary level.<ref name=cp/> Learning hours at school are often less than four hours per day.<ref name=cp/> Skill shortages are present at all levels of the education system, and funding for and access to education vary significantly by gender (with [[Dropping out|dropout]] rates much higher for girls) and location.<ref name=cp/>
The overall [[literacy rate]] in Eritrea is estimated to be about 67.8 percent, with young adults aged 15–24, 89 percent literate.<ref>[https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/er.html Eritrea]. CIA World Factbook</ref><ref>[http://data.worldbank.org/country/eritrea Eritrea]. World Bank</ref> "The Ministry [of Education] plans to establish a university in every region in the future."<ref name="college" />
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.scuoleasmara.it/scuola/scuola-coloniale.html Colonial School system in Eritrea, by Silvia Nocchi (in Italian)]
{{Education in Africa}}
[[Category:Education in Eritrea| ]]

The '''European Girls' Mathematical Olympiad''' is a [[mathematical olympiad]] for girls which started in 2012. It is similar to, and was inspired by, the [[China Girls Mathematical Olympiad]].<ref name="info">{{cite web|url=https://www.egmo2012.org.uk/information/|accessdate=30 July 2012|title=European Girls' Mathematical Olympiad 2012: Information}}</ref> <ref name=bmoweb>{{cite web|title=BMOS/BMOC: European Girls' Mathematical Olympiad|url=https://bmos.ukmt.org.uk/home/egmo.shtml}}</ref>
==EGMO 2012== The first EGMO took place in April 2012 at [[Murray Edwards College, Cambridge]] and was run by the [[United Kingdom Mathematical Trust]]. Nineteen countries took part: [[Belgium]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Finland]], [[Hungary]], [[Indonesia]], [[Ireland]], [[Italy]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Latvia]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Poland]], [[Romania]], [[Saudi Arabia]], [[Serbia]], [[Switzerland]], [[Turkey]], [[Ukraine]], the [[United Kingdom]] and the [[United States of America]].<ref name="countrylist">{{cite web|title=Countries at EGMO 2012|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo1/countries/}}</ref>
There were two four-and-a-half hour examinations, which were held at the [[Centre for Mathematical Sciences (Cambridge)|Centre for Mathematical Sciences]].<ref name="info"/>
==EGMO 2013== The second EGMO took place in April 2013 in [[Luxembourg]] and was run by the Association des Mathématiciens du Luxembourg in cooperation with the [[Lycée Aline Mayrisch]]. 22 countries took part.
==EGMO 2014== The third EGMO was held in April 2014 in [[Antalya]], organized by [[TÜBİTAK]]. 29 countries took part.<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2014|url=http://egmo2014.tubitak.gov.tr/}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2014 in Turkey|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo3/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2015== The fourth EGMO was held in April 2015 in [[Minsk]]. 30 teams took part.<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2015 in Belarus|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo4/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2016== The fifth EGMO was held in April 2016 in [[Bușteni]]. 39 teams took part.<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2016 in Romania|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo5/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2017== The sixth EGMO was held in April 2017 in [[Zürich]]. 44 teams took part.<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2017 in Switzerland|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo6/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2018== The seventh EGMO was held in April 2018 in [[Florence]]. 52 teams took part.<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2018 in Italy|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo7/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2019== The eighth EGMO will be held in 2019 in [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2019 in Ukraine|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo8/}}</ref>
==EGMO 2020== The ninth EGMO will be held in 2020 in the [[Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web|title=EGMO 2020 in the Netherlands|url=https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo9/}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * https://www.egmo.org/ * [https://www.egmo2012.org.uk/ European Girls' Mathematical Olympiad 2012] * [https://www.egmo.org/egmos/egmo2/ European Girls' Mathematical Olympiad 2013]

{{Refimprove|date=October 2017}} {{expand language|topic=|langcode=ru|otherarticle=Паррот, Георг Фридрих|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Georg Friedrich Parrot | image = Georg Friedrich Parrot.jpg | alt = Georg Friedrich Parrot | caption = Georg Friedrich Parrot. Portrait by Pavel Smirnov, Saint Petersburg. | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1767|07|15}} | birth_place = [[Montbéliard|Mömpelgard]], [[Duchy of Württemberg]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1852|07|08|1767|07|05}} | death_place = [[Helsinki|Helsingfors]], [[Grand Duchy of Finland]], [[Russian Empire]] | nationality = [[Russian Empire]] | fields = [[Physics]] | workplaces = [[University of Tartu|University of Dorpat]], [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Russian Imperial Academy of Sciences]] | alma_mater = [[University of Stuttgart]], [[University of Königsberg]] | known_for= First rector of the Imperial University of Dorpat }} '''Georg Friedrich Parrot''' (15 July 1767 – 8 July 1852) was a [[Germany|German]] [[scientist]], the first [[Rector (academia)|rector]] of the [[University of Tartu|Imperial University of Dorpat]] (today [[Tartu]], [[Estonia]]) in what was then the [[Governorate of Livonia]] of the [[Russian Empire]].<ref>Joseph Thomas [https://books.google.com/books?id=r1oWAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA1895 Universal pronouncing dictionary of biography and mythology, Volume 2] 1901</ref>
==Education== Georges-Frédéric Parrot was born in Mömpelgard (now [[Montbéliard]]) (then part of the [[Duchy of Württemberg]], from 1806 in France). His father, a [[surgeon]] by profession and the local duke’s [[physician]] in ordinary, had a respectable position in the society becoming the [[mayor]] of his hometown. As the family was [[Protestants]], they sent Georg Friedrich to study [[physics]] and [[mathematics]] at the [[University of Stuttgart]] in [[Stuttgart]], the capital of the Duchy (1782–1786).
==Career beginnings== For several years after graduation, Parrot took positions as a private [[tutor]] in France and Germany, and in 1795 in Livonia, one of the [[Baltic governorates|Baltic provinces]] of the Russian Empire. His reasons for leaving [[Germany]] were mainly economic: as he was recently married, he needed a more regular income than he could gain from giving occasional private classes in mathematics and attending to various contests of [[invention]]s. His talent was noticed and he was appointed to be the first secretary of the Livonian Charitable and Economic Society (''Livländische gemeinnützige und ökonomische Sozietät'') founded in 1796 in [[Riga]], the capital of Livonia, for the promotion of [[science]] and new ideas of management. At that time, there was no longer a [[university]] in the region. Although King [[Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden]] had founded the [[Academia Gustaviana]] in 1632, it had ceased to exist in 1710 when [[Peter the Great]] had conquered the [[Baltic Sea]] provinces. Only in 1802 was the university re-founded by the order of the [[Tsar]] [[Alexander I of Russia|Alexander I]] as the only [[German language|German-language]] and [[Lutheran]] university in the Russian Empire. Parrot was initially appointed to the Chair of Pure and Applied Mathematics but after defending his [[doctoral dissertation]] “On the influence of Physics and Chemistry on Pharmacy” (''Über den Einfluss den Physic und Chemie auf die Arzneikunde'') in 1802, he was appointed to the Chair of Physics.
==Imperial University of Dorpat== Due to his extraordinary energy, he became the first rector of the [[Imperial University of Dorpat]] (University of Tartu), being elected by the University Council consisting of all chaired professors. In this capacity, Parrot skillfully fought for the academic freedom and the self-government of the university, protecting her from the political pressure of Baltic German [[baron]]s who had been given the right to autonomously govern in the Baltic provinces. The university was re-opened on the initiative of the local aristocratic establishment but they disliked Parrot for his unconcealed sympathy to the ideals of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]]. Parrot openly talked about [[Social equality|equality]] of people, irrespective of their social status and heritage. In his inaugural speech at the opening ceremony of the University he said, addressing the students: [[File:TKM 1240G, Tartu Ülikooli peahoone, Georg Friedrich Schlater.jpg|thumb|250px|The Imperial University of Dorpat, 1832–1835.]] {{Quote frame|text=While you are using with a laudatory diligence all that science and art are able to provide for the benefit of your culture, the countryman is working for you on his field; he is devoting his toil for you, working in the hardest conditions all his days, even part of the nights, and because of that he is enforced to fall behind you in his cultural development. [...] You understand that those who feed you are entitled to much more than merely a miserable existence, that they have every right to expect your gratitude, your respect, our gratitude, our respect.}}
According to the memoirs of Parrot’s contemporaries, these words made an inextinguishable impression. However, Parrot’s hour of triumph arrived on May 22, 1802. Tsar Alexander I stopped in [[Dorpat]] on his way to [[Klaipėda|Memel]] (Klaipėda) for the meeting with the King [[Frederick William III]] of [[Prussia]]. Parrot was nominated to give a speech in his honour with which he immediately won the sympathy of the young ambitious Tsar. Appealing to the ideal of enlightened monarchy, Parrot expressed his gratitude to the Tsar who had ordered the reopening of the university, and repeated the promise to honestly serve science and the whole humanity. Alexander was so delighted with Parrot’s eloquence that he asked him to prepare a written copy of his speech. This episode laid the foundations of a friendly relationship between the Tsar and Parrot, which lasted for ten years and proved to be extremely beneficial for the University, to say nothing about Parrot himself.
In 1811, Parrot was elected to be a corresponding member of the [[Russian Academy of Sciences|Imperial Academy of Sciences]], becoming a full member in 1826. In the same year, he retired from the University of Dorpat and continued his work as a head of the physics laboratory of the Academy of Sciences in [[Saint Petersburg]]. He died on a trip to [[Helsingfors]] (Helsinki), in 1852.
The Parrot dynasty left an indelible mark on the [[Science and technology in Russia|history of science in Russia]] and Estonia. His son, [[Friedrich Parrot]] (1791-1841), followed in his father's footsteps, making a career as a [[Natural history|naturalist]] and later assuming the rectorship at the University of Dorpat in 1830. A pioneer of Russian and Estonian scientific mountaineering, he is best known for leading the first expedition to the summit of [[Mount Ararat]] in recorded history.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Randveer|first1=Lauri|title=How the Future Rector Conquered Ararat|url=http://www.ut.ee/en/how-future-rector-conquered-ararat|publisher=[[University of Tartu]]}}</ref><ref name="RBTH">{{cite web|last=Giles|first=Thomas|title=Friedrich Parrot: The man who became the 'father of Russian mountaineering'|url=http://rbth.com/arts/literature/2016/04/27/friedrich-parrot-the-man-who-became-the-father-of-russian-mountaineering_588545|work=[[Russia Beyond the Headlines]]|date=27 April 2016}}</ref>
==250th Anniversary== On the occasion of Parrot's upcoming 250th anniversary, University of Tartu purchased Parrot's original rector portrait, thought to have been lost, at an auction. The portrait was revealed at the Old Anatomical Theatre in Tartu in the summer of 2017.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Eljand-Kärp|first1=Viivika|title=200-year-old painting of G. F. Parrot to be exhibited for the first time in UT Art Museum|url=https://www.ut.ee/en/news/200-year-old-painting-g-f-parrot-be-exhibited-first-time-ut-art-museum|publisher=[[University of Tartu]]|date=3 July 2017}}</ref> The [[Vanemuine]] theatre staged the play ''Anima In Machina. G. F. Parrot'' in his honour in 2017.<ref>Anima In Machina. G. F. Parrot http://www.vanemuine.ee/repertuaar/vaim-masinas-g-f-parrot/?lang=en</ref> [[Estonian Association of the History and Philosophy of Science]] along with the University of Tartu Museum hosted an international three day conference "On the Border of the Russian Empire: German University of Tartu and its first Rector Georg Friedrich Parrot" in his honour.
== References == <references/>
{{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Elof Holstenius]] | title=Rector of [[University of Dorpat]] | years=1802–1803 | after=[[Daniel Georg Balk]]}} {{succession box | before=[[Adam Christian Gaspari]] | title=Rector of [[University of Dorpat]] | years=1805–1806 | after=[[Carl Friedrich Meyer]]}} {{succession box | before=[[David Hieronymus Grindel]] | title=Rector of [[University of Dorpat]] | years=1812–1813 | after=[[Martin Ernst von Styx]]}} {{s-end}}

{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Gustav Langenscheidt | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Gustav_Langenscheidt.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1832|10|21}} | birth_place = [[Berlin]], [[Prussia]] | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1895|11|11|1832|10|21}} | death_place = [[Berlin]], [[Prussia]] | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = West [[Stahnsdorf]], [[Germany]] | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = [[Prussia]] | nationality = [[Germany|German]] | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Founder of [[Langenscheidt|Langenscheidt Publishing Group]] | notable_works = ''Encyklopädisches französisch-deutsches und deutsch-französisches Wörterbuch'' ("Encyclopedic French-German and German-French dictionary");
''Encyklopädisches englisch-deutsches und deutsch-englisches Wörterbuch'' ("Encyclopedic English-German and German-English dictionary") | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = {{marriage|Pauline Hartmann|1857|1895}} (his death) | partner = | children = 2 daughters, 4 sons | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Gustav Langenscheidt''' (October 21, 1832 – November 11, 1895) was a [[Germans|German]] [[language teacher]], [[book publisher]], and the founder of [[Langenscheidt|Langenscheidt Publishing Group]]. == Life == Gustav Langenscheidt was the son of Johann Ludwig Langenscheidt, a decorator, and his wife Sophie Caroline Schwartze. After graduating from high school in 1850 Langenscheidt started a commercial apprenticeship, which he completed in two years. Between 1851 and the spring of 1853 Langenscheidt traveled to almost all the neighboring countries of Germany and covered around 7000 kilometers on foot and by stagecoach. After returning to Germany he joined the army in summer of 1853. During his time in the military Langenscheidt extensively studied the different ways of learning the [[French language]]. In 1857, he married Pauline Hartmann (1832 – 1903) in [[Berlin]] and had two daughters and four sons, including the writer and publisher [[Paul Langenscheidt]] and Carl Langenscheidt, who later became his successor. Gustav Langenscheidt died on November 11, 1895, at the age of nearly 63 years. He was first buried in the old St. Matthew's Cemetery in [[Schöneberg]], and then in his final resting place in the family grave in West [[Stahnsdorf]] in 1935. The family's [[mausoleum]] is in Department D of the cemetery. == Work == [[File:Toussaint-Langenscheidt Spanisch 30.59-60.png|thumb|Example title page of a language learning letter for [[Spanish language|Spanish]], which uses the [[Toussaint-Langenscheidt method]]]] Together with [[Charles Toussaint]] Langenscheidt developed a self-learning method, which he published in 1856 under the title ''Unterrichtsbriefe zur Erlernung der französischen Sprache'' ("Teaching letters for learning the French language"). Langenscheidt had copied the idea of such a teaching method and especially the sales strategy of [[William Cobbett]]. Since no publisher was interested in this teaching work, Langenscheidt himself established a publishing house on October 1, 1856. These correspondence lessons became very popular and were widely read, so today Langenscheidt can be considered the "Father of [[distance education]]." In 1857 Langenscheidt was appointed chief writer of the 11th Infantry Brigade in Berlin. In 1861, together with [[Carl Dalen]] and Henry Lloyd, Langenscheidt published "English lessons letters" (similar in structure to the French). From 1867 Langenscheidt Publishing Group had its own [[printing press]]. From 1869 Langenscheidt worked with [[Karl Sachs]] and [[Césaire Villatte]] on the ''Encyklopädisches französisch-deutsches und deutsch-französisches Wörterbuch'' ("Encyclopedic French-German and German-French dictionary") and was finally able to publish it in 1880. In 1874, Langenscheidt was awarded the title of professor. In 1891, in close collaboration with [[Eduard Muret]] and [[Daniel Sanders (lexicographer)|Daniel Sanders]], he started working on the English equivalent, the ''Encyklopädisches englisch-deutsches und deutsch-englisches Wörterbuch'' ("Encyclopedic English-German and German-English dictionary"). Langenscheidt did not live to see its publication; his son Carl, his successor, published it in 1901. The [[Toussaint-Langenscheidt method]] is based on the language teaching methodology of [[James Hamilton (language teacher)|James Hamilton]] and [[Jean Joseph Jacotot]]. The revolutionary aspect of this method was that the focus was no longer on grammar, but on reading and communication. Langenscheidt and Toussaint created a new [[phonetic transcription|phonetic alphabet]] for the representation of pronunciation in order to facilitate learning. This was used until the [[Second World War]], after which it was replaced by the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]] (IPA). == Honors == * The Langenscheidt bridge in Berlin is named after Gustav Langenscheidt. * The Gustav Langenscheidt School in Berlin is named after him. == References == * {{NDB|13|587|588|Langenscheidt, Gustav|Walter Voigt|117584916}} == External links == * [http://www.langenscheidt.de/verlagsgruppe/gustav_langenscheidt_96.html Detailed biography of Gustav Langenscheidt on the Langenscheidt Publishing Group's website] * [http://www.gustav-langenscheidt.schule-berlin.net/ Homepage of the Gustav Langenscheidt School in Berlin] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Langenscheidt, Gustav}} [[Category:Language teachers]] [[Category:German book publishers (people)]] [[Category:1832 births]] [[Category:1895 deaths]]

{{Infobox organization | name = HighWire Press | formation = {{start date and age|1995}} | purpose = | location = Los Gatos, California, USA; Belfast, Northern Ireland, UK; Brighton, England, UK | leader_title = CEO | leader_name = Dan Filby | leader_title2 = Founding Director | leader_name2 = John Sack | website = {{URL|https://highwirepress.com}} }} '''HighWire Press''' is a US company that provides [[digital content]] development and [[hosting service]]s to ~140 influential societies, university presses and independent publishers that produce journals, books, and other scholarly publications. It was founded by [[Stanford University Libraries]] in 1995.<ref name="HighwireAbout">{{cite web |url=https://www.highwirepress.com/about-us |title=About us |publisher=HighWire Press |accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref>
HighWire also offers Bench>Press,<ref>http://highwire.org/publishers/benchpress.dtl</ref> a customizable peer-review manuscript submission and tracking system, used by ~65 publishers.
In 2014, majority ownership of HighWire Press was purchased by the [[private equity firm]] [[Accel-KKR]].<ref>[http://home.highwire.org/news/stanford-university%E2%80%99s-highwire-press-receives-growth-equity-investment-accel-kkr Stanford University’s HighWire Press receives Growth Equity Investment from Accel-KKR]</ref>
In 2017, it was announced that the entirety of the journals published by HighWire Press would be indexed in [[Meta (academic company)|Meta]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.highwirepress.com/thought-leadership/news/ai-tool-meta-index-all-content-highwire-platform-increase-rapid|title=AI Tool Meta to Index All Content on HighWire Platform to Increase Rapid Discoverability |website=www.highwirepress.com |date=22 June 2017 |language=en|access-date=2018-03-15}}</ref>
==Content== HighWire-hosted publishers collectively make over 2 million articles available (out of 7.5 million articles) freely accessible.<ref name="HighwireFree">{{cite web |url= http://highwire.stanford.edu/lists/freeart.dtl |title=Free online full-text articles |date=2014-01-14 |work=HighWire |accessdate=2014-02-03}}</ref>
In 1995, the ''[[Journal of Biological Chemistry]]'' (JBC) (1905) published by the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, was the first to launch online on the HighWire platform. Since then, a number of other journals use the technology service to develop and host their online content. Titles include, among many others: * ''[[Science (journal)|Science]]'' (1880) American Association for the Advancement of Science * ''[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]]'' (PNAS), (1914) National Academy of Sciences * ''[[eLife]]'' from elifesciences * ''[[Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society]]'' (the oldest continuously published journal) from the Royal Society * ''[[American Journal of Botany]]'' (1914) by the Botanical Society of America * ''[[The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition]] (1952) by the American Society for Nutrition * ''[[Blood (journal)|Blood]]'' (1945) by the American Society of Hematology * ''[[BMJ]]'' (British Medical Journal, 1840) BMJ Group, UK * ''[[The EMBO Journal]]'', (1982) by the European Molecular Biology Organization, Germany * ''[[The FASEB Journal]]'', (1987) Federation of American Societies for Experimental Biology * ''[[Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery]]'', (1903) * ''[[Journal of Cell Biology]]'', (1955) Rockefeller University Press
The organization has grown significantly since its inception in 1995. In addition to journals, HighWire produces and hosts ebooks, conference proceedings, databases, and more. They use open source technologies, such as Drupal, as part of the front end of the newest version of the websites.
==Reviews and awards== While HighWire is primarily a hosting facility, a 2007 study showed that its search engine outperformed [[PubMed]] in the identification of desired articles, and yielded a higher number of search results than when the same search was performed on PubMed. PubMed, however, was faster.<ref name="pmid17184763">{{cite journal |vauthors=Vanhecke TE, Barnes MA, Zimmerman J, Shoichet S |title=PubMed vs. HighWire Press: a head-to-head comparison of two medical literature search engines |journal=Comput. Biol. Med. |volume=37 |issue=9 |pages=1252–8 |year=2007 |pmid=17184763 |doi=10.1016/j.compbiomed.2006.11.012}}</ref>
HighWire was the recipient of the 2003 [[Association for Learned and Professional Society Publishers]] (ALPSP) Award for "Service to Not-for-Profit Publishing", and was named one of the "Ten to Watch" organizations in the Scientific, Technical & Medical information space in 2014 by Outsell.<ref>http://www.outsellinc.com/store/products/1211</ref> Founding Director John Sack was awarded the Council of Science Editors (CSE) 2011 Award for Meritorious Achievement.<ref>http://www.councilscienceeditors.org/wp-content/uploads/v34n3p76.pdf</ref>

[[File:Madingley-Hall.jpg|thumb|The Institute's headquarters at Madingley Hall]] The '''Institute of Continuing Education''' (ICE) is a constituent part of the [[University of Cambridge]]. The institute encourages people in all walks of life to take advantage of [[continuing education]].
==Offerings, students, and staff== ICE offers residential, online, weekend, summer, and part-time courses, as well as public lectures.<ref name="CN1"/> The Institute also provides free public concerts performed by [[Cambridge]] musicians, featuring new student work alongside more traditional repertoire.<ref>[http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/event/Ghislaine-McMullin-plays-Russian-cello-music/event-26046123-detail/event.html "Ghislaine McMullin plays Russian cello music”], ''[[Cambridge News]]'' (February 18, 2015).</ref><ref>[http://www.ice.cam.ac.uk/what-we-do/madingley-concerts “University of Cambridge Institute of Continuing Education: Welcome to the Madingley Concerts”], Accessed June 17, 2015; [http://www.ice.cam.ac.uk/what-we-do “University of Cambridge Institute of Continuing Education: What We Do”], Accessed June 17, 2015.</ref>
The Institute has an enrollment of over 6,000 students and has an academic staff of 13. A summer program brings in another 1,000 students from over 60 countries.<ref name="CN1">{{cite web|author1= Care, Adam|title=You’re never too old for a Cambridge education|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/8217-old-Cambridge-education/story-23299689-detail/story.html|publisher=''[[Cambridge News]]''|accessdate=June 13, 2015|date=October 24, 2014}}</ref> The academic staff are called "lecturers", and the Institute's teaching is also accomplished by a group of about 300 "tutors" located in the Cambridge area and elsewhere.<ref name=CN1 /><ref name=Barlow>Barlow, Adrian. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=NKYABAAAQBAJ&pg=PA19 Extramural: Literature and Lifelong Learning]'', pp. 18-19. (Lutterworth Press 2012).</ref>
ICE offers course credits via the United Kingdom's [[Credit Accumulation and Transfer Scheme]], and those credits may be transferable to other Cambridge degree programs, and to other U.K. and U.S. universities.<ref name=Henderson /> The duration of study varies, from one and two-day courses, through two-year part-time master's degrees, and courses are often taken for personal interest or for professional development.<ref name="CN1" />
==Headquarters and history== The Institute's headquarters is in the village of [[Madingley]], [[Cambridgeshire]]. It is housed in Madingley Hall, about four miles west of the Cambridge city limits.<ref name= Henderson /> Madingley Hall was built in the 1540s and was later rented by [[Queen Victoria]] for the young [[Prince of Wales]] (later [[Edward VII]]) while he was a student at Cambridge.<ref name="CN1"/><ref name=Henderson /><ref name="CN2">{{cite web|author1= Care, Adam|title=More than 380 species discovered at Cambridge University's Madingley Hall|url=http://www.cambridge-news.co.uk/380-species-discovered-Cambridge-University-s/story-26376175-detail/story.html|publisher=''[[Cambridge News]]''|accessdate=June 13, 2015|date=April 23, 2015}}</ref>
ICE moved to Madingley Hall in 1975,<ref name="CN1" /> but has been educating part-time and adult students since the 1860s.<ref name=Henderson>Henderson, C.W. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=r3rDaCO-VFkC&pg=PT87 Open the Gates to the Ivy League: A Plan B for Getting into the Top Colleges]'', p. 87 (Penguin 2013).</ref> It is the oldest continuing education department in the [[United Kingdom]].<ref name="CN1" />
The founder of ICE was University of Cambridge scientist [[James Stuart (scientist)|James Stuart]].<ref name=Barlow /><ref>[http://m.cambridge-news.co.uk/Institute-Continuing-Education-sponsor-Team-Year/story-26503588-detail/story.html "Institute of Continuing Education to sponsor Team of the Year prize at News' Junior Sports Award"], ''[[Cambridge News]]'' (May 15, 2015).</ref> In 1867, Stuart gave a course of lectures in various cities, which marked the beginning of the university extension movement. The University of Cambridge sanctioned the movement a few years later, in 1873, with the first course offered in [[Derby]] that year.<ref>Jarvis, Peter. ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=SMMgRnWmf3YC&pg=PA318 Adult Education and Lifelong Learning: Theory and Practice]'', p. 318 (Routledge 2004).</ref>
==Supervision by university== In 2008, when Cambridge University indirectly offered its stamp of approval for certificates in things like "garden history" and "creative writing", the university faced accusations of [[dumbing down]].<ref name=Bingham>Bingham, John. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/education/universityeducation/3902094/Garden-history-and-wellbeing-qualifications-from-Cambridge-University.html "Garden history and 'wellbeing' qualifications from Cambridge University”], ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' (December 22, 2008).</ref> According to ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', the university decided to, "take over the awarding of certificates currently offered by bodies such as the Cambridge Institute of Continuing Education….”<ref name=Bingham />
Today, the work of ICE is controlled by the General Board of the University, through a management committee. The institute's lecturers are all appointed by the University.<ref name=Barlow /> {{multiple image | align=center | image1 = Madingley Hall, topiary and grounds - geograph.org.uk - 796851.jpg | width1 = 220 | image2 = Tudor staircase, Madingley Hall, Cambridgeshire, from below.jpg | width2 = 200 | image3 = Madingley Hall, archway into courtyard - geograph.org.uk - 796857.jpg | width3 = 220 | image4 = Madingley Hall and lake - geograph.org.uk - 986964.jpg | width4 = 220 | footer = From left to right (all at Madingley Hall): [[topiary]]; old [[Tudor architecture|Tudor]] staircase seen from below; archway into courtyard; lake | footer_align = center }}
