{{pp-pc1}} {{Infobox person | name = Mehmet Öz | image = Mehmet Oz - World Economic Forum Annual Meeting 2012.jpg | birth_name = Mehmet Cengiz Öz | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|6|11}} | birth_place = [[Cleveland, Ohio]], U.S. | occupation = Talk show host, surgeon, author | children = 4 | spouse = {{marriage|[[Lisa Oz|Lisa Lemole]]|1985}} | years_active = 1982–present | education = [[Harvard University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BS]])}}
[[University of Pennsylvania]] {{small|([[Doctor of Medicine|MD]], [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]])}} | website = {{url|doctoroz.com|Official website}} }} '''Mehmet Cengiz Öz''' ({{IPA-tr|mehˈmet dʒenˈɟiz øz|lang}}; born June 11, 1960),{{cite web| url = http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/mehmet-oz/215510/ | title= Mehmet Oz | publisher=[[TV Guide|TVGuide.com]] | access-date= January 12, 2016}} known professionally as '''Dr. Oz''', is a [[Turkish Americans|Turkish American]]{{cite web |url= http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/1688472/Mehmet-Oz |title=Mehmet Oz biography – Turkish American surgeon, educator, and author |first=Amy |last=Tikkanen |work=Encyclopædia Britannica |year=2015 |access-date=February 24, 2015}}{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1185906/bio |title=Mehmet Oz – Biography | publisher = [[Internet Movie Database]] |year=2015 |access-date=February 24, 2015}} [[television personality]], [[cardiothoracic surgeon]], [[Columbia University]] professor, [[pseudoscience]] promoter,{{Cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/04/17/physicians_urge_columbia_to_drop_its_unacceptable_affiliation_with_pseudoscience_promoter_dr_oz/|title=Physicians urge Columbia to drop its "unacceptable" affiliation with pseudoscience promoter Dr. Oz|last=Abrams|first=Lindsay|website=Salon|access-date=2017-06-19|date=2015-04-17}} and [[author]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.newsmax.com/FastFeatures/Green-Coffee-Beans-Extract-Reviews-Congress-Investigation-Supplements/2015/03/16/id/630396/|title=Green Coffee Beans Extract Reviews: What Congress Found In Its Investigation|work=Newsmax|access-date=2017-06-19}} Oz came to general prominence with appearances on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' beginning in 2004, and later on ''[[Larry King Live]]'' and other TV programs. In 2009, ''The Dr. Oz Show'', a daily television program focusing on medical issues and personal health, was launched by Winfrey's [[Harpo Productions]] and [[Sony Pictures]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/article/pressroom/pressrelease/20080613_orig_drozsony|title=Harpo Productions and Sony Pictures Television To Launch Dr. Oz|work=Oprah.com|date=June 13, 2008}} He is a proponent of [[alternative medicine]], and has been criticized by physicians, government officials, and publications, including ''[[Popular Science]]'' and ''[[The New Yorker]]'', for giving non-scientific advice and promoting [[pseudoscience]]. In a Senate hearing on weight loss scams, Senator [[Claire McCaskill]] chided Oz, saying: "The scientific community is almost monolithic against you in terms of the efficacy of the three products you call miracles".{{Cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2014/06/17/dr-oz-senate-panel-weight-scams/10701067/ |title=Senators scold Dr. Oz for weight-loss scams |last=Mutnick |first=Ally |date=2014-06-17 |work=USA Today}} In 2014 the [[British Medical Journal]] examined over 400 medical or health recommendations from 40 episodes of his program and found that only 46% of his claims were supported by reputable research, while 15% of his claims contradicted medical research and the remainder of Oz's advice were either vague banalities or unsupported by research. ==Early life== Oz was born in 1960 in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], to Suna and Mustafa Öz, who had emigrated from [[Konya Province]], [[Turkey]].{{cite news|first=Lana|last=Zak|title=Dr. Oz on Complementary Medicine: 'Challenge the Status Quo'|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/OnCall/story?id=8450292|work=Good Morning America|date = August 31, 2009|access-date= October 12, 2009}}{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/facesofamerica/profiles/dr-mehmet-oz/4/ |title=Faces of America: Dr. Mehmet Oz |work=[[Faces of America (PBS series)|Faces of America]]'' series, with Professor [[Henry Louis Gates|Henry Louis Gates, Jr.]] |year=2010}} Mustafa, born in [[Bozkır]], a small town in central Turkey, earned scholarships that allowed him to emigrate to the United States as a [[Residency (medicine)|medical resident]] in 1955. Suna (née Atabay), who comes from a wealthy [[İstanbul]] family, is the daughter of a [[pharmacist]] with [[Circassians|Circassian]] ([[Shapsug]]) descent on her mother's side. Oz has two sisters, Seval Öz and Nazlim Öz.{{cite news |title=Dr. Mehmet Öz'ün Düzce'ye uzanan soyağacı |url=http://jinepsgazetesi.com/index.php?module=news&news_id=11655&cat_id=106 |work=Jineps |date= January 1, 2011 |access-date= September 17, 2011 |language=Turkish}} Oz was educated at [[Tower Hill School]] in [[Wilmington, Delaware|Wilmington]], [[Delaware]].{{cite web | url=http://www.phillymag.com/articles/exit-interview-dr-oz/ | title=Exit Interview: Dr. Oz | publisher=[[Metrocorp]] | work=[[Philadelphia (magazine)|Philadelphia]] | date=October 30, 2009 | access-date=March 11, 2014 | last=Rys |first=Richard}} In 1982, he received his undergraduate degree in biology at [[Harvard University]].{{cite news |url= http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=7641721&privcapId=79086309&previousCapId=29249600&previousTitle=The%20Cue%20Ball%20Group,%20LLC|work=Business Week |title= Executive Profile: Mehmet C. Oz M.D |access-date=January 12, 2011}} In 1986, he obtained [[Doctor of Medicine|MD]] and [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] degrees respectively at the [[University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine]] and Penn's [[Wharton School]].{{cite news|first=Lizzy |last=Ratner |title=The Great and Powerful Dr. Oz |url=http://www.nyobserver.com/2007/great-and-powerful-dr-oz |work=[[New York Observer]] |date= August 14, 2007 |access-date= September 24, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020021729/http://www.nyobserver.com/2007/great-and-powerful-dr-oz |archive-date=October 20, 2007 }} He was awarded the Captain's Athletic Award for leadership in college{{cite web| url= http://www.abc.daytonsnewssource.com/sections/entertainment/droz |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100704070306/http://abc.daytonsnewssource.com/sections/entertainment/droz/ | year=2010| publisher= WKEF-TV |archive-date= July 4, 2010 | title= Mehmet C. Oz, M.D.}} and was [[class president]] and then [[student body president]] during medical school.{{cite web |url= http://www.talkshows.about.com/od/thedrozshow/p/DrOzBio.htm |title=Dr Oz – The Dr Oz Show |publisher=about.com |access-date= May 22, 2010}} ==Career== Oz has been a professor at the Department of Surgery at [[Columbia University]] since 2001.{{cite web|url=http://asp.cumc.columbia.edu/facdb/profile_list.asp?uni=mco2&DepAffil=Surgery |title=Mehmet C. Oz, MD, FACS – Department of Surgery |publisher=Columbia University |date= |access-date= September 16, 2011}} He directs the Cardiovascular Institute and Complementary Medicine Program at [[New York-Presbyterian Hospital]].{{cite web|url=http://bigthink.com/mehmetoz |title=Mehmet Oz | Professor, Columbia University |publisher=Big Think |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} His research interests include heart valve replacement surgery, minimally invasive cardiac surgery, and health care policy. In 2010, Oz joined [[Jeff Arnold (Internet entrepreneur)|Jeff Arnold]] as co-founder of [[Sharecare|Sharecare, Inc.]],{{cite web |url=http://www.health2con.com/news/2010/10/18/san-francisco-2010-launch-of-sharecare/ |title=Sharecare, Inc. |publisher=Health 2.0 |access-date=March 12, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208104438/http://www.health2con.com/news/2010/10/18/san-francisco-2010-launch-of-sharecare/ |archive-date=December 8, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} providing an interactive question and answer platform for industry experts to answer health-related questions.{{cite news|url=https://blogs.forbes.com/zinamoukheiber/2010/11/16/names-you-need-to-know-in-2011-sharecare/ |title=Names You Need To Know In 2011: Sharecare |publisher=Forbes.com |date= November 16, 2010 |access-date= April 1, 2011 |first=Zina |last=Moukheiber}} ===Television, radio and films=== {{Infobox television | italic_title = no | show_name = The Dr. Oz Show | image = The Dr. Oz Show logo.png | genre = [[Talk show]] | creator = [[Oprah Winfrey]] | presenter = Mehmet Oz | country = United States | language = English | num_seasons = 9 | num_episodes = 1,000+ {{cite web|title=Episodes: ''The Dr. Oz Show''|url=http://www.doctoroz.com/episode/oz-celebrates-his-1000th-show-hugh-jackman|work=TV Guide|accessdate=November 29, 2015}} | executive_producer = {{Plainlist| * Stacy Rader * Amy Chiaro }} | location = | camera = [[Multiple-camera setup|Multiple]] | runtime = 44 minutes | company = * ZoCo Productions
(2009–2010)
(season 1) * [[Harpo Productions|Harpo Studios]]
(2010–2017)
(seasons 2-8) * OzWorks
(2010–2017)
(seasons 2-8) * Oz Media
(2017–present)
(season 9-present) | distributor = [[Sony Pictures Television]] | picture_format = [[1080i]] ([[High-definition television|HDTV]]) | first_aired = {{Start date|2009|9|14}} | last_aired = present | website = http://www.doctoroz.com/ | channel = [[Broadcast syndication|Syndication]] }} [[File:Michelle Obama and Dr. Mehmet Oz learn a dance routine during a taping of the “Dr. Oz Show”, 2013.jpg|thumb|[[Michelle Obama]] and Mehmet Oz learn a dance routine during a taping of the "Dr. Oz Show", 2013]] Oz appeared as a health expert on ''The Oprah Winfrey Show'' for five seasons.{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/contributor/dr-mehmet-oz |title=Live your best Life |publisher=Oprah.com |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} His show debuted September 14, 2009. The show is co-produced by Oprah Winfrey's [[Harpo Productions]] and distributed by Sony Pictures Television. It is the second ''Oprah'' spin-off series featuring a regular guest (''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'' being the first), and it marks the first time that Winfrey's company has partnered with another studio outside of the current [[CBS Television Distribution]], which co-produces her series as well as her other series. This is assumed to be because ''The Dr. Oz Show'' is in direct competition with the ''Dr. Phil'' spinoff ''[[The Doctors (talk show)|The Doctors]]'', which CBS distributes. For the first four seasons, shows were recorded in Studio 6A at [[NBC Studios (New York City)|NBC Studios]] in New York,{{cite web|url=http://www.myfoxny.com/subindex/health/Dr_Oz |title=Dr. Oz — New York News | NYC Breaking News |publisher=Myfoxny.com |date= |accessdate=November 26, 2012}} but vacated [[Rockefeller Center]] after NBC reclaimed the space for its ''[[Late Night (NBC)|Late Night]]'' franchise.{{cite web|last=Bond|first=Paul|title=NBC Dumps $25 Million Jimmy Fallon NYC 'Tonight Show' Studio|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jimmy-fallon-tonight-show-nbc-518867|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=September 4, 2013|date=May 7, 2013}} Beginning with season five, ''Dr. Oz'' originates from ABC Television Center East on the [[Upper West Side]] of [[Manhattan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.doctoroz.com/get-show-tickets|title=Get Show Tickets!|website=www.doctoroz.com}} On the show, Oz addressed issues like Type 2 [[diabetes]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/health/2010-02-04-Oprahdiabetes04_ST_N.htm|work=USA Today|title=Oprah Winfrey takes on a killer: type 2 diabetes|date= February 4, 2010|access-date= January 12, 2011}} and promoted [[resveratrol]] supplements, which he stated were anti-aging.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/15/mehmet-oz-oprah-business-media-resveratrol.html|first=Dirk|last=Smillie|work=Forbes|title=A Headache For Dr. Oz|date=16 June 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090619083439/http://www.forbes.com/2009/06/15/mehmet-oz-oprah-business-media-resveratrol.html|archive-date= June 19, 2009}} His ''Transplant!'' television series won both a Freddie{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreddies.com/Awards/Results.aspx?CategoryId=17&Year=2006 |title=The FREDDIE Awards |publisher=Thefreddies.com |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} and a Silver Telly award.{{cite web|url=http://www.tellyawards.com/winners/list/?l=L&event=7&category=1&award=S |title=The 31st Annual TELLY Awards | Winners |publisher= TellyAwards.com |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} He served as medical director for [[Denzel Washington]]'s ''[[John Q]]''.{{cite web |url= https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251160/fullcredits#cast |title=John Q (2002) – Full Cast & Crew | publisher = [[Internet Movie Database]] |year=2015 |access-date= February 24, 2015}} In January 2011, Oz premiered as part of a weekly show on [[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|OWN]] called "Oprah's Allstars". In each episode, he, [[Suze Orman]], and [[Dr. Phil]] answer various questions about life, health and finance. He also currently does a health segment on [[1010 WINS]] titled "Your Daily Dose".{{Cite web|url=http://rbr.com/westwood-one-brings-dr-oz-to-wins-am-new-york/|title=Westwood One brings Dr. Oz to WINS-AM New York {{!}} Radio & Television Business Report|last=cmarcucci|website=rbr.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-05-08|date=November 2010}} On October 23, 2014, ''Surgeon Oz'', showing Oz's career as a surgeon, debuted on OWN.{{cite web|url=http://decoy.tvpassport.com/news/dealing-demons-comic-book-renaissance-continues-nbc?subid=national-00001|title=Dealing with demons: Comic book renaissance|last=Warren|first=Andrew|publisher=TV Media}} ===Author=== Oz co-authored, with [[Michael F. Roizen]], six ''New York Times'' best sellers including ''You: The Owner's Manual'', ''You: The Smart Patient'', ''You: On a Diet'', ''You: Staying Young'', ''You: Being Beautiful'' as well as ''Healing from the Heart''. His book ''You: Having a Baby'' was published by Free Press in 2009. He has a regular column in ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'' magazine and ''[[O, The Oprah Magazine]]'' and his article "Retool, Reboot, and Rebuild" was awarded the 2009 National Magazine Award for Personal Service.{{cite web|url=http://www.magazine.org/asme/magazine_awards/nma_winners |title=American Society of Magazine Editors – 2010 National Magazine Awards Winners Announced! |publisher=Magazine.org |date= April 22, 2010 |access-date= May 22, 2010}} Oz and the [[Hearst Corporation]] launched the bi-monthly magazine ''Dr. Oz THE GOOD LIFE'' on February 4, 2014.{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2014/01/26/dr-oz-magazine-launch-set-for-feb-4/ |title=Dr. Oz magazine launch set for Feb. 4 | work =[[New York Post]] |date= January 26, 2014 |access-date= April 14, 2014}} ===Recognition=== [[File:Dr. Oz at ServiceNation 2008.jpg|thumb|Mehmet Oz at [[ServiceNation]] in 2008]] ''Time'' magazine ranked Oz at 44th on its list of the "100 Most Influential People in 2008"{{cite news| url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/article/0,28804,1733748_1733754_1735329,00.html | work=Time | title=The 2008 Time 100 | date= April 30, 2009 | access-date= May 12, 2010}} and ''Esquire'' magazine placed him on its list of the "75 Most Influential People of the 21st Century".{{cite web|last=Five |first=Column |url=http://www.esquire.com/features/most-influential-21st-century-1008 |title=Influential People – 21st Century | work = [[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |date= September 16, 2008 |access-date= May 22, 2010}} He was named one of "The Harvard 100 Most Influential Alumni" by ''02138'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://neco.org/profileList.php?list=o |title=Listing |publisher=Neco.org |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} He was listed in "Doctors of the Year" by ''Hippocrates'' magazine and in "Healers of the Millennium" by ''Healthy Living'' magazine.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/mehmet-oz/bio/215510 |title=Mehmet Oz Biography |publisher=tvguide.com |access-date= May 1, 2010}} Other awards and honors include: *2010 [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Host]] *2011 Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Host *2011 [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Informative]] *2012 Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Informative *2013 Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Informative *2016 [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Informative Talk Show Host]]{{cite news|url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/TV/2016/05/02/General-Hospital-Live-with-Kelly-Michael-win-big-at-the-Daytime-Emmy-Awards/2271462123287/|date=May 2, 2016|title='General Hospital,' 'Live with Kelly & Michael' win big at the Daytime Emmy Awards|author=Butler, Karen| publisher = [[United Press International]] |access-date=May 2, 2016}} *2017 Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Informative *2018 Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Informative ==Controversy== Oz has faced criticism due to his tendency to feature non-scientific and [[pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] advice. ===Arsenic in apple juice=== In September 2011, Oz drew criticism for a show focusing on the alleged dangers of arsenic in apple juice. Oz hired an independent toxicology laboratory, EMSL, and found arsenic levels in some samples to be above the limit the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) allows in drinking water.{{cite web|url=http://www.doctoroz.com/videos/arsenic-apple-juice |title=Arsenic in apple juice – Dr Oz's extensive national investigation |publisher=Doctoroz.com |date= September 9, 2011 |access-date= March 28, 2013}} The FDA said "there is currently no evidence to suggest a public health risk", and criticized the emphasis on measurements of total arsenic without distinguishing between harmless organic arsenic compounds and toxic inorganic arsenic compounds that pose differing levels of health risk.[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504763_162-20106763-10391704.html "Apple juice safe despite arsenic, FDA tells Dr. Oz"]. [[CBS News]]. September 15, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.medpagetoday.com/PrimaryCare/DietNutrition/28528 |title=FDA Slams 'Dr. Oz' for Apple Juice Report |publisher=Medpagetoday.com |date= September 15, 2011 |access-date= March 28, 2013}}[http://abcnews.go.com/Health/dr-richard-besser-dr-mehmet-oz-debate-arsenic/story?id=14526426 "Apple Juice Showdown: Dr. Oz Arsenic Claim Questioned by Dr. Besser"]. [[ABC News]]. September 15, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.doctoroz.com/videos/dr-oz-answers-your-questions-about-arsenic-apple-juice |title=Dr. Oz Answers Your Questions About Arsenic in Apple Juice | The Dr. Oz Show |publisher=Doctoroz.com |date= September 15, 2011 |access-date= March 28, 2013}} [[Consumer Reports]] conducted similar tests on samples of apple and grape juices around the same time. Unlike the tests done by Oz, Consumer Reports tested for both organic and inorganic types of arsenic. Results showed that 6% (5 out of 80) of the samples tested by Consumer Reports exceeded the 10-parts-per-billion (ppb) federal limit for arsenic in drinking water. When counting only inorganic arsenic, one of the 80 apple juice samples tested slightly exceeded 10-parts-per-billion limit, at 10.48 ppb.{{cite web|author=The Atlantic Wire |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2011/12/dr-oz-vindicated-new-study-finds-high-arsenic-levels-in-apple-juice/249331/ |title=Dr. Oz Vindicated: New Study Finds High Arsenic Levels in Apple Juice |publisher=Theatlantic.com |date= December 1, 2011 |access-date= March 28, 2013}}{{cite news|url=http://news.consumerreports.org/safety/2011/11/consumer-reports-tests-juices-for-arsenic-and-lead.html |title=Consumer Reports tests juices for arsenic and lead |publisher=Consumer Reports |date=November 30, 2011 |access-date= May 19, 2013}} The limits only apply to arsenic levels for drinking water; there are no legal limits for arsenic in fruit juices. After the ''Dr. Oz Show'' aired, the FDA indicated it is continuing to research the levels of arsenic in fruit juices and other foods, and may implement limits for fruit juices in the future.{{cite web |url=http://www.doctoroz.com/videos/fda-statement-arsenic-apple-juice |title=FDA Statement: Arsenic in Apple Juice |author=Food and Drug Administration |date=November 29, 2011 |publisher=doctoroz.com |access-date=May 19, 2013}} ===Real Age drug marketing=== Oz is a spokesman and advisor for the website [[RealAge]].com, which ''[[The New York Times]]'' has criticized for its pharmaceutical marketing practices. The site solicits medical information from visitors to determine a visitor's biological age and then uses the visitor's medical profile for pharmaceutical marketing purposes. As ''The Times'' reporter explained the significance of this fact: "While few people would fill out a detailed questionnaire about their health and hand it over to a drug company looking for suggestions for new medications, that is essentially what RealAge is doing."{{cite news |title=Online Age Quiz Is a Window for Drug Makers |author=Stephanie Clifford |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/26/technology/internet/26privacy.html |newspaper= [[The New York Times]] |date=March 25, 2009 |access-date=May 20, 2012}} ===Reparative therapy of homosexuals=== A November 28, 2012 episode of ''[[The Dr. Oz Show]]'' was devoted to [[reparative therapy]],{{Cite newspaper |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/29/dr-oz-reparative-ex-gay-therapy-backlash-_n_2211621.html |title=Dr. Oz's Reparative Or 'Ex-Gay' Episode Prompts Backlash From GLAAD, PFLAG And GLSEN | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | access-date= January 25, 2013|date=2012-11-29 }} "forms of therapy that are designed to turn a gay person straight",{{cite blog | url = https://blog.doctoroz.com/dr-oz-blog/reparative-therapy-controversy | date = 2012-11-28 | title = The Reparative Therapy Controversy | first = Mehmet | last = Oz | work = Dr. Oz Blog | publisher = [[Harpo, Inc.]] | accessdate = 2018-02-02 }} all of which have been directly rejected by the mainstream mental health professions.{{cite book | url = https://www.apa.org/pi/lgbt/resources/just-the-facts.pdf | author = Just the Facts Coalition | year = 2008 | title = Just the facts about sexual orientation and youth: A primer for principals, educators, and school personnel | location = Washington, D.C. | publisher = American Psychological Association | accessdate = 2018-02-01 | page = 5 | quote = The most important fact about these "therapies" is that they are based on a view of homosexuality that has been rejected by all the major mental health professions. }} The broadcast featured Julie Hamilton, a representative of the [[National Association for Research and Therapy of Homosexuality]] (NARTH), which offers reparative therapy, and also had guests who condemned it.{{cite news release | url = https://www.glaad.org/releases/lgbt-organizations-condemn-dr-oz-show-episode-so-called-reparative-therapy-ask-dr-oz-stand | date = November 28, 2012 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121203140252/https://www.glaad.org/releases/lgbt-organizations-condemn-dr-oz-show-episode-so-called-reparative-therapy-ask-dr-oz-stand | archivedate = 2012-12-03 | author1 = [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation]] | author2 = [[Gay, Lesbian & Straight Education Network]] | author3 = [[PFLAG National]] | title = LGBT Organizations Condemn Dr. Oz Show for Episode on So-Called Reparative Therapy, Ask Dr. Oz to Stand Up for His LGBT Viewers | publisher = Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation | location = Los Angeles }} Three of the groups who were consulted for the show — [[Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation|GLAAD]], [[Gay, Lesbian & Straight Education Network|GLSEN]], and [[PFLAG National]] — issued a joint press release repudiating the episode just after it aired. The press release, calling NARTH "a splinter group of anti-gay therapists/activists", criticized the episode for starting with two segments of the show featuring proponents of reparative therapy without challenge, then introducing the NARTH representative as an "expert", and providing no opinion by Dr. Oz on the subject, which the press release authors characterized as causing the audience to be "misled to believe that there are actual experts on both sides of this issue". The press release also stated that "GLSEN would not have participated in The Dr. Oz Show had we known that NARTH would be represented". Oz responded in a blog post, mentioning the opposition of respected medical organizations to the practice of reparative therapy, and saying that "if we want to reach everyone who might benefit from understanding the risks of this therapy, you have to present multiple perspectives." He also said that he agreed "with the established medical consensus", that he had "not found enough published data supporting positive results with gay reparative therapy", and that he was concerned about "potentially dangerous effects when the therapy fails". Oz also pointed out that "the guests who appeared on my show on either side of this debate agreed that entering into any therapy with guilt and self-hate is a major error." ===June 2014 Senate hearing=== During a Senate hearing on consumer protection, Senator [[Claire McCaskill]] stated that by airing segments on weight loss products that are later cited in advertisements, Oz plays a role, intentional or not, in perpetuating these scams, and that she is "concerned that you are melding medical advice, news, and entertainment in a way that harms consumers."{{cite web |title=Senate Sub-Committee for Commerce, Science, and Transportation Hearing on Protecting Consumers from False and Deceptive Advertising of Weight-Loss Products |url=http://www.commerce.senate.gov/public/index.cfm?p=Hearings&ContentRecord_id=c1698871-3625-4f67-b0e5-a06d3bab6ca1&ContentType_id=14f995b9-dfa5-407a-9d35-56cc7152a7ed&Group_id=02096e14-bdcc-424b-842c-d6809f3f69c9 |date=June 17, 2014}} Mary Engle of the [[U.S. Federal Trade Commission]] (FTC) criticized Oz for calling [[green coffee extract]] "magic" and a "miracle", stating that it is difficult for consumers to listen to their inner voices when products are praised by hosts they trust. One of the products Oz was promoting, Green Coffee Bean Extract, was found to have no weight loss benefits. Two of the researchers who were paid to write the study admitted that they could not back their data so they retracted their paper. The FTC filed a complaint that the Texas-based company Applied Food Sciences (the promoters of the study) had falsely advertised. The FTC alleged that the study was "so hopelessly flawed that no reliable conclusions could be drawn from it" so Applied Food Sciences agreed to pay a $3.5 million settlement.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/dr-oz-endorsed-green-coffee-bean-diet-study-retracted/ |title=Dr.Oz-endorsed diet pill study was bogus, researchers admit |publisher=CBS News |date= October 20, 2014 |access-date= February 24, 2015}}{{cite web|last=Saunders |first=Russell |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/cheats/2014/10/20/green-coffee-bean-dr-oz-study-retracted.html |title=Dr. Oz Green Coffee Bean Study Retracted |publisher=The Daily Beast |date= 2014-10-20|access-date= February 24, 2015}} ===Lack of scientific validity=== [[File:McCaskill Takes Aim at Diet Scams That Are 'A Crisis in Consumer Protection'.webm|thumb|right|Oz was heavily criticised by Senator [[Claire McCaskill]] in a hearing on consumer fraud in diet product advertising.]] ''[[Popular Science]]''{{cite web | url=http://www.popsci.com/science/article/2013-01/dr-oz-bad-science | title=Is Dr. Oz Bad For Science? | work=[[Popular Science]] | date=January 30, 2013 | access-date=March 11, 2014 | author=Lecher, Colin}} and ''[[The New Yorker]]''{{cite web | url=http://www.newyorker.com/reporting/2013/02/04/130204fa_fact_specter | title=The Operator | work=[[The New Yorker]] | date=February 4, 2013 | access-date=March 11, 2014 | author=[[Michael Specter|Specter, Michael]]}} have published critical articles on Oz for giving "non-scientific" advice. These criticisms include questioning if he is "doing more harm than good" and pointing out his "irresponsible and dangerous" treatment of eating disorders.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}} The [[James Randi Educational Foundation]] has awarded Oz with their [[Pigasus Award]], an award intended "to expose parapsychological, paranormal or psychic frauds that Randi has noted over the previous year."{{cite web |url= http://archive.randi.org/site/index.php/component/content/article/37-static/256-pigasus-awards.html |title=Pigasus Awards |first=Jeff |last=Wagg | publisher =James Randi Educational Foundation |date=October 31, 2008 |access-date= February 24, 2015}} The award consists of a silver flying pig and refers to claiming something so doubtful that it will only happen "[[when pigs fly]]". Oz has been given this award on three separate occasions, more than any other recipient: *In 2009 for the promotion of energy therapies such as [[Reiki]].{{cite web |title=Pigasus Awards |url=http://archive.randi.org/site/index.php/swift-blog/928-the-2009-pigasus-awards.html |publisher=James Randi Education Foundation |date= April 2, 2010 | access-date= October 14, 2014}} *In 2010 for support of [[faith healing]] and [[mediumship|psychic communication with the dead]], among other controversial practices. Oz became the first person to receive a Pigasus Award two years in a row.{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/health/boostershots/la-heb-dr-oz-andrew-wakefield-james-randi-awards-20110401,0,3573991.story | title=Dr. Oz, Andrew Wakefield and others, um, 'honored' by James Randi | access-date=April 2, 2011 | author=Mestel, Rosie | date=April 1, 2011 | work= [[Los Angeles Times]]}} *In 2012, Oz won "The Pigasus Award for Refusal to Face Reality" for his continued promotion of "quack medical practices, paranormal belief, and pseudoscience".{{cite web|last1=Randi|first1=James|authorlink=James Randi|title=JREF's Pigasus Awards "Honors" Dubious Peddlers of "Woo" |url=http://archive.randi.org/site/index.php/jref-news/2074-jrefs-pigasus-awards-honors-dubious-peddlers-of-woo.html |publisher=James Randi Education Foundation |date= April 1, 2013 |access-date= October 14, 2014}} Oz has also been supportive of [[homeopathy]].{{cite web | url=http://www.doctoroz.com/videos/homeopathy-starter-kit-pt-1 | title=Homeopathy Starter Kit, Pt 1 |work=[[The Dr. Oz Show]] | date=January 28, 2013 | access-date=May 22, 2014 }} As well, Oz's image and quotes have been used in many weight loss product [[scam]]s. While he himself has not been found to be involved in these scams, he has made statements that were exploited by scammers.{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/06/17/dr-oz-gets-scolded-by-senators-over-weight-loss-scams/ |title=Dr. Oz gets scolded by senators over weight loss scams |publisher = [[Fox News]] |date=June 17, 2014 |access-date=February 24, 2015}} Oz has stated that he is a proponent of [[alternative medicine]] and that he makes great efforts to inform viewers that he neither sells nor endorses any supplements. A study published in the British Medical Journal on the effectiveness of Oz's medical advice found that only 46 percent of his recommendations had any scientific backing or rationale.{{cite news|last1=McCoy|first1=Terrence|title=Half of Dr. Oz's medical advice is baseless or wrong, study says|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/12/19/half-of-dr-ozs-medical-advice-is-baseless-or-wrong-study-says/| work = [[The Washington Post]] |date= December 19, 2014}} The study showed that 39 percent had no supporting scientific evidence, while the remaining 15 percentage points went directly against scientific evidence.{{cite news|last1=Apstein|first1=Adam|title=Research confirms it: Dr. Oz dispenses a lot of medical advice with no scientific grounding|url=http://qz.com/315813/research-confirms-it-dr-oz-dispenses-a-lot-of-medical-advice-with-no-scientific-grounding/|agency=Quartz|date= December 20, 2014}} In April 2015, a group of ten physicians from across the United States, including Henry Miller, a fellow in scientific philosophy and public policy at Stanford University's Hoover Institute, sent a letter to Columbia University calling Oz's faculty position unacceptable. They accused Oz of "an egregious lack of integrity by promoting quack treatments and cures in the interest of personal financial gain".[http://www.cnn.com/2015/04/17/health/dr-oz-columbia-letter/ "Physicians to Columbia University: 'Dismayed' that Dr. Oz is on faculty"]. [[CNN]]. April 18, 2015. ==Personal life== [[File:Lisa Oz Mehmet Oz David Shankbone 2010.jpg|thumb|Oz and his wife Lisa]] Oz lives in [[Cliffside Park, New Jersey|Cliffside Park]], [[New Jersey]], with his wife [[Lisa Oz|Lisa]].{{cite news | author = [[Frank Bruni|Bruni, Frank]] | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/magazine/18Oz-t.html |title=Dr. Does-It-All |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 16, 2010 |access-date=March 22, 2011 |quote=That is his base line, to which he adds more yoga, short runs and basketball games with friends near his home in Cliffside Park, N.J., when he can.}} They have been married since 1985Married on July 29, 1985 in Bryn Athyn, PA – ''New Church Life'', 1985, p. 430. and have four children. His eldest daughter is author and television host [[Daphne Oz]]. Oz is fluent in English and [[Turkish Language|Turkish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.talkturkey.us/2009/07/the-wizard-of-dr-oz.html |title=The Wizard of Dr Oz – talkturkey |publisher=Talkturkey.us |date= July 19, 2009 |access-date= May 22, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100520011523/http://www.talkturkey.us/2009/07/the-wizard-of-dr-oz.html |archive-date=May 20, 2010 }} He is a holder of [[Turkish nationality law|Turkish]] and American citizenship, having served in the [[Turkish Army]] to retain his Turkish citizenship.{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/30/magazine/the-experiments-of-dr-oz.html?pagewanted=3 | work= [[The New York Times]] | title=The Experiments of Dr. Oz | first=Chip | last=Brown | date= July 30, 1995 | access-date= May 12, 2010}} Oz grew up in a mixed [[Muslim]] environment where his father's family practiced more traditional [[Islam]], while his mother's family were more [[secular]] Muslims.{{cite video |people=Dr. Oz |year= 2010|title=Islam and Identity |url=https://www.pbs.org/wnet/facesofamerica/video/islam-and-identity/140/ |format=Flash Video |medium= |trans_title= |publisher=PBS |location= |access-date= April 22, 2010}} Oz identifies himself as a Muslim{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/these-9-famous-americans-are-all-muslim-2014-10|title=9 Famous Americans You Probably Didn't Know Were Muslim |publisher=businessinsider.com |date= October 27, 2014 |access-date= April 20, 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wfaa.com/story/news/health/2014/08/10/13618098/|title=Dr. Oz: The inside story |publisher=[[WFAA|WFAA.com]] |date= August 10, 2014 |access-date= April 20, 2015}} and says that he has been influenced by the mysticism of [[Sufi]] Muslims from Central Turkey,{{cite web|url=http://www.theroot.com/multimedia/meet-faces-america-dr-mehmet-oz |title=Henry Louis Gates Jr. Faces of America: Dr. Mehmet Oz |publisher=Theroot.com |date= August 19, 2010 |access-date= August 28, 2010}} as well as the ideas of [[Emanuel Swedenborg]], the 18th century Swedish theologian, scientist, philosopher, revelator and mystic.{{cite journal |authorlink=Martin Gardner |last=Gardner |first=Martin |year=2010 |title=Swedenborg and Dr. Oz. |journal=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |volume=34 |number=5 |url=http://www.csicop.org/si/show/swedenborg_and_dr._oz/}}{{cite web |url=http://www.spirituality-health.com/NMagazine/articles.php?id=1768 |title=Spirituality & Health: Mehmet Oz Finds His Teacher |publisher=Spirituality-health.com |date= |access-date= May 22, 2010}} Oz is a practitioner of [[Transcendental Meditation technique|transcendental meditation]]. "When I meditate, I go to that place where truth lives", he said. "I can see what reality really is, and it is so much easier to form good relationships then."{{cite news| url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/features/tribu/ct-tribu-skube-multitasking,0,5213589.column | work=Chicago Tribune | title=Become a wizard of multitasking! | first=Daneen | last=Skube}} In August 2010, Oz was diagnosed with a pre-cancerous [[Polyp (medicine)|polyp]] in the colon during a routine [[colonoscopy]]{{cite news| url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/09/dr-oz-high-risk-after-cancer-scare/1 | work=USAToday.com | title=Dr. Oz 'high risk' after cancer scare | date= September 1, 2010 | access-date= October 18, 2010}} which was performed as part of his show. Oz said that the procedure likely saved his life.{{cite news| url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20417551,00.html |work=People |title=Dr. Oz Has Colon Cancer Scare |first=Charlotte |last=Triggs |date= September 1, 2010| access-date= November 30, 2010}} ==Bibliography== *''Healing from the Heart: A Leading Surgeon Combines Eastern and Western Traditions to Create the Medicine of the Future'', by Mehmet Öz, [[Ron Arias]], [[Dean Ornish]], 1999, {{ISBN|0-452-27955-0}}. *''Complementary and Alternative Cardiovascular Medicine: Clinical Handbook'', by Richard A. Stein (Editor), Mehmet, M.D. Oz (Editor), 2004, {{ISBN|1-58829-186-3}}. *''YOU: The Owner's Manual: An Insider's Guide to the Body that Will Make You Healthier and Younger'', by [[Michael F. Roizen]], Mehmet C. Oz, 2005, {{ISBN|0-06-076531-3}}. *''YOU: On a Diet: The Owner's Manual for Waist Management'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2006, {{ISBN|0-7432-9254-5}}. *''YOU: The Smart Patient: An Insider's Handbook for Getting the Best Treatment'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2006, {{ISBN|0-7432-9301-0}}. *''YOU: Staying Young: The Owner's Manual for Extending Your Warranty'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2007, {{ISBN|0-7432-9256-1}}. *''YOU: Being Beautiful: The Owner's Manual to Inner and Outer Beauty'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2008, {{ISBN|1-4165-7234-1}}. *''YOU: Breathing Easy: Meditation and Breathing Techniques to Help You Relax, Refresh, and Revitalize'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2008. *''YOU: Having a Baby: The Owner's Manual from Conception to Delivery and More'', by Michael F. Roizen, Mehmet C. Oz, 2009. *''Minimally Invasive Cardiac Surgery'', by Mehmet C. Oz, 2010, {{ISBN|1-61737-400-8}}. *Numerous editorials in ''[[TIME]]'', ''[[Newsweek]]'', [[O, The Oprah Magazine|''O'' Magazine]], ''Esquire'' Magazine, and ''[[The New England Journal of Medicine]]'' ==Television shows== *''Second Opinion with Dr Oz'' on [[Discovery Channel|Discovery]] during the 2003–04 season *''Life Line'' on Discovery Health *''Daily Rounds'' on Discovery Health *''The Truth About Food'' on Discovery Health *''Live Transplant'' on Discovery Health *''National Body Challenge'' on Discovery Health *''You: On a Diet'' on Discovery Health *''Ask Dr. Oz'' on [[The Oprah Winfrey Show]] *''[[AccentHealth]]'' on Turner Private Networks—a health-themed [[newsmagazine]] program designed for viewing in doctor's offices *''[[The Dr. Oz Show]]'', Syndicated *''Your Life A to Z with Dr. Oz{{cite web|url=http://www.azfamily.com/on-tv/your-life/Dr-Oz-Cooking-for-your-health-142214275.html |title=Dr. Oz: Cooking for your health}} *''[[NY Med]]'' on ABC *[[Dr. Ken]] on ABC (January 11, 2016) ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last=Brown |first=Heidi |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/08/04/oprah-health-doctor-forbeslife-cx_hb_0804oz.html |title=Oprah Loves This Doctor |journal=[[Forbes|Forbes magazine]] |date=August 4, 2008 |access-date=June 1, 2015}} * {{cite journal |last=Specter |first=Michael |authorlink=Michael Specter |date=February 4, 2013 |title=The operator : is the most trusted doctor in America doing more harm than good? |department=Profiles |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |volume=88 |issue=46 |pages=40–49 |url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/02/04/the-operator |access-date=January 9, 2015}} ** {{Cite news |last=Gladstone |first=Brooke |author-link=Brooke Gladstone |title=Dr. Oz Fights for Credibility |url=http://www.onthemedia.org/story/dr-oz-fights-credibility/ |work=[[On the Media]] |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=April 24, 2015 |access-date=June 1, 2015}} Discussion with Michael Specter about his profile of Oz. ==External links== {{Commons category|Mehmet Oz}} * {{official website|http://www.DoctorOz.com/|name=Official website of ''The Dr. Oz Show''}} * [http://columbiasurgery.org/mehmet-c-oz-md-facs Columbia University Department of Surgery profile] * {{IMDb name|1185906}} {{Daytime Emmy Award Outstanding Talk Show Host}} {{Daytime Emmy Award Outstanding Talk Show Informative}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Oz, Mehmet}} [[Category:1960 births]] page.title: Mexican International Conference on Artificial Intelligence

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 3 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox Academic Conference | history = 2000– | discipline = [[Artificial Intelligence]] | abbreviation = MICAI | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] [[Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence|LNAI]], [[IEEE]] CPS, journals. | country= International | frequency = annual }} The '''Mexican International Conference on Artificial Intelligence (MICAI)''' is the name of an annual [[Meeting|conference]] covering all areas of [[Artificial Intelligence]] (AI), held in [[Mexico]]. The first MICAI conference was held in 2000. The conference is attended every year by about two hundred of AI researchers and PhD students and 500−1000 local graduate students. == Overview == MICAI is a high-level peer-reviewed international conference covering all areas of Artificial Intelligence. All editions of MICAI have been published in Springer [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] [[Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence|LNAI]] (N 1793, 2313, 2972, 3789, 4293, 4827, 5317, 5845, 6437–6438). Recent MICAI events (2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, and 2010) received over 300 submissions from over 40 countries each. The conference's scientific program includes keynote lectures, paper presentations, tutorials, panels, posters, and workshops. MICAI is organized by the [[Mexican Society for Artificial Intelligence]] (SMIA) in cooperation with various national institutions. Their topics of interest include, but are not limited to: [[Applications of artificial intelligence]], [[Automated theorem proving]], [[Belief revision]], [[Bioinformatics]] and [[Medical applications of artificial intelligence]], [[Case-based reasoning]], [[Common-sense reasoning]], [[Computer vision]] and [[image processing]], [[Constraint programming]], [[Data mining]], [[Expert systems]] and [[knowledge-based systems]], [[Fuzzy logic]], [[Genetic algorithms]], [[Hybrid intelligent systems]], [[Intelligent interfaces]]: [[multimedia]], [[virtual reality]], [[Intelligent organizations]], [[Intelligent tutoring systems]], [[Knowledge acquisition]], [[Knowledge representation]] and [[knowledge management]], [[Logic programming]], [[Machine learning]], [[Model-based reasoning]], [[Multiagent systems]] and [[distributed artificial intelligence]], [[Natural Language Processing]], [[Artificial neural network|Neural Networks]], [[Non-monotonic Reasoning]], [[Ontology|Ontologies]], [[Pattern Recognition]], [[Philosophical and methodological issues of artificial intelligence]], [[Planning and scheduling]], [[Qualitative reasoning]], [[Robotics]], [[Spatial and remporal reasoning]], [[Uncertainty reasoning]] and [[probabilistic reasoning]]. == Specific MICAI conferences == In the table below, the figures for the number of accepted papers and acceptance rate refer to the main proceedings volume and do not include supplemental proceedings volumes. The number of countries corresponds to submissions, not to accepted papers. {| class="wikitable" |- !Year !City !Website !Proceedings !Submissions !Countries !Accepted !Acceptance rate |- |2000 |[[Acapulco]] |[http://www.MICAI.org/2000/]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} |{{Cite journal | editor1-last = Cairó | editor1-first = Osvaldo | editor2-first = Luis Enrique | editor3-first = Francisco J.| title = MICAI 2000: Advances in Artificial Intelligence | doi = 10.1007/10720076 | series = Lecture Notes in Computer Science | volume = 1793 | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-3-540-67354-5 | pmid = | pmc = | editor2-last = Sucar | editor3-last = Cantu }} |163 |17 |60 |37% |- |2002 |[[Mérida (Yucatán)|Mérida]] |[http://www.MICAI.org/2002/]{{dead revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} [[Image:Torbjorn01.jpg|thumb|Torbjørn Røe Isaksen is Norway's Minister of Education and Research]] '''Royal Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research''' ({{lang-no|Kunnskapsdepartementet}}, lit. ''Ministry of Knowledge'') is a [[Politics of Norway|Norwegian government]] ministry responsible for [[education in Norway|education]], research and [[kindergarten]]s. The ministry was established in 1814, and is since 16 October 2013 led by [[Torbjørn Røe Isaksen]] ([[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]]).
The department reports to the legislature ([[Storting]]et). Traditionally this ministry was also responsible for church affairs, but this function was transferred to the [[Norwegian Ministry of Culture and Church Affairs|Ministry of Culture and Church Affairs]] in 2002.
==Organisations== ===Political staff<ref>[http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/kd/about-the-ministry/other-political-staff.html?id=608 Ministry of Education and Research - Political staff]</ref>=== * [[Torbjørn Røe Isaksen]], minister of Education and Research ([[Conservative Party (Norway)|Conservative Party]]) * State Secretaries, [[Bjørn Haugstad]] and [[Birgitte Jordahl]] * Political Adviser, [[Magnus Thue]]
===Departments=== * Department of Administration and Development * Department of Early Childhood Education and Care<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/kd/About-the-Ministry/Organisation.html?id=610 |title=Organisation |accessdate=June 27, 2007 |author=Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research}}</ref> * Department of Education and Training * Department of Governance and Finance * Department of Higher Education * Department of Policy Analysis, Lifelong Learning and International Affairs * Department of Research * The Communication Unit
===Subsidiaries=== The following [[etat|government agencies]] are subordinate to the ministry:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.regjeringen.no/nb/dep/kd/dep/Underliggende-etater.html?id=115208 |title=Underliggende etater |accessdate=June 27, 2007 |author=Norwegian Ministry of Education and Research |language=Norwegian}}</ref> * [[Research Council of Norway]] ''Norges forskningsråd'' ([http://www.forskningsradet.no/en/Home_page/1177315753906 Official site]) In charge of research funding and research policy. * [[Norwegian Directorate for Education and Training]], or ''Utdanningsdirektoratetet'' ([http://www.udir.no Official site]) Responsible for the development of primary and secondary education. Approves the primary and secondary school curriculum. * [[Centre for ICT in education]] * [[Foreldreutvalget for grunnskolen]] ([http://www.fug.no/forside.138180.en.html Official site]) Cooperation between parents and school authorities. * [[Norway Opening Universities]], or ''Norgesuniversitetet'' ([http://norgesuniversitetet.no/about Official site]) Think tank for lifelong learning and e-learning in higher education and provides funding to distance learning initiantives. * [[Norwegian Agency for Quality Assurance in Education]], or ''Nasjonalt organ for kvalitet i utdanningen'' ([http://www.nokut.no/en/ Official site]) Quality assurance for colleges and secondary vocational training, as well as approving degrees from foreign countries. * [[Norwegian Centre for International Cooperation in Higher Education]], or ''Senter for internasjonalisering av høyere utdanning'' ([http://www.siu.no Official site]) Promotes international cooperation in higher education and research. * [[Norwegian Institute for Adult Learning]], or ''VOX-læring for arbeidslivet'' ([http://www.vox.no/templates/CommonPage.aspx?id=3239 Official site]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) Promotes adult learning within reading, writing, arithmetic and ICT. * [[Norwegian Institute of International Affairs]], or ''Norsk utenrikspolitisk institutt'' ([http://www.nupi.no Official site]) Foreign policy research. * [[Norwegian Meteorological Institute]], or ''Meteorologisk institutt'' ([http://www.met.no Official site]) Performs weather observations and forecasts. * [[Norwegian Social Research]], or ''Norsk institutt for forskning om oppvekst, velferd og aldring'' ([http://www.nova.no Official site]) Research. * [[Norwegian State Educational Loan Fund]], or ''Statens lånekasse for utdanning'' ([http://www.lanekasen.no Official site]) Grands loans and scholarships to students. * [[Norwegian Universities and Colleges Admission Service]], or ''Samordna opptak'' ([http://www.samordnaopptak.no Official site]) Coordinates admission to most undergraduate courses at state universities and colleges. * [[Statens fagskole for gartnere og blomsterdekoratører]] ([http://www.sgbd.no Official site]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}) Educates gardeners and flower decorators at secondary school level.
===Universities=== * [[Nord University]], or '' Nord universitet'' ([http://www.nord.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian University of Life Sciences]], or ''Universitetet for miljø- og biovitenskap'' ([http://www.unb.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian University of Science and Technology]], or ''Norges teknisk-naturvitenskapelige universitet'' ([http://www.ntnu.no Official site]) * [[University of Bergen]], or ''Universitetet i Bergen'' ([http://www.uib.no Official site]) * [[University of Oslo]], or ''Universitetet i Oslo'' ([http://www.uio.no Official site]) * [[University of Stavanger]], or ''Universitetet i Stavanger'' ([http://www.uis.no Official site]) * [[University of Tromsø]], or ''Universitetet i Tromsø'' ([http://www.uit.no Official site]) * [[University of Agder]], or ''Universitetet i Agder'' ([http://www.hia.no Official site])
===Specialised Colleges=== * [[Oslo School of Architecture and Design]], or ''Arkitektur- og designhøgskolen i Oslo'' ([http://www.aho.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian School of Economics and Business Administration]], or ''Norges handelshøgskole'' ([http://www.nhh.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian School of Sport Sciences]], or ''Norges idrettshøgskole'' ([http://www.nih.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian Academy of Music]], or ''Norges musikkhøgskole'' ([http://www.nmh.no Official site]) * [[Norwegian School of Veterinary Science]], or ''Norges vetrinærhøgskole'' ([http://www.veths.no Official site])

revision.text:
The '''Northern Territory Certificate of Education''' (NTCE) is the credential awarded to [[High School]] students who successfully complete senior high school level studies (years 11 and 12 or equivalent) in the [[Northern Territory]], [[Australia]].
==The NTCE structure== NTCE is normally taught in years 11 and 12 of senior high school in the Northern Territory. There are two levels: Stage 1, generally taught in Year 11, and Stage 2, taught in Year 12. At least 22 approved units must be studied.
Each NTCE subject is organised into units, there is a list of subjects available to senior secondary students through Territory schools. Students can select up to 9 free choice units from Stage 1 and/or Stage 2 subject offerings. Each territory school can provide a list of senior subjects it offers.
Secondary students work towards the Northern Territory Certificate of Education. The [[Northern Territory Board of Studies]] issues the certificate to students who meet the requirements of achievement during their studies.
==Calculation of the Tertiary Entrance Rank== The TER is calculated by the [[South Australian Tertiary Admissions Centre]] (SATAC) for students who successfully complete the Northern Territory Certificate of Education (NTCE) and fulfill certain other criteria to qualify for a TER.
Results for the NTCE are forwarded to SATAC by the [[Northern Territory Board of Studies]].
==See also== *[[Education in Australia]] *[[Tertiary Entrance Rank]]
==External links== *[http://www.deet.nt.gov.au/education/parents/senior_secondary_schooling.shtml NT Government] *[http://www.deet.nt.gov.au/education/ntbos/ntce.shtml NT Board of Studies] *[http://www.ssabsa.sa.edu.au/nt/index.php]
