{{Contains Burmese text}} The '''University Entrance Examination''' ({{lang-my|တက္ကသိုလ်ဝင်တန်း စာမေးပွဲ}}) is an academic examination administered to 10th standard students at all schools in Myanmar, including government schools, comprehensive schools and private boarding schools, for students seeking university admission. The test is administered at least 3 weeks after the Basic Education High School Examination.<ref name="wde">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibe.unesco.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/WDE/2010/pdf-versions/Myanmar.pdf|title=Myanmar|date=2010|work=World Data on Education|accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref> Test results determine the eligibility of high school students to pursue higher education, and their entrance into select universities and majors.
The current college admission system is being revised by the [[Ministry of Education (Burma)|Ministry of Education]].<ref name="mtn">{{cite news|url=http://www.mmtimes.com/index.php/special-features/207-education-2015/14534-university-application-process-to-be-reformed.html|title=University application process to be reformed|last=May Thinzar Naing|date=18 May 2015|work=Myanmar Times|accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref> Beginning in the 2015-16 academic year, students will be able to sit for entrance exams at the universities of their choice. Further, students will be allowed to retake such exams.<ref name="mtn"/>
==Administration== The University Entrance Examination is administered by the [[Board of Examinations]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Announcement for submitting matriculation exam applications |newspaper=The New Light of Myanmar |date=2007-09-14 |url=http://myanmargeneva.org/NLM2007/eng/9Sep/n070914.pdf |accessdate=2010-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110428013548/http://myanmargeneva.org/NLM2007/eng/9Sep/n070914.pdf |archive-date=2011-04-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Each year, there are eleven question papers of equal format for Burmese states and regions.<ref name="kirk">{{cite journal|last=Kirkpatrick|first=Robert |author2=Hmone Lian Hlaing |date=29 May 2013|title=The Myanmar university entrance examination|journal=Language Testing in Asia|publisher=Springer|volume=3|issue=14|url=http://www.languagetestingasia.com/content/3/1/14}}</ref> The system of eleven test papers per year was adopted in 2001-02 to prevent the leakage of some questions prior to the exam administration.<ref name="kirk"/>
In [[Yangon]], sales of alcohol are banned during matriculation exam administration.<ref>{{cite news |title=No booze as students cram for their exams |newspaper=Myanmar Times | author=Ye Ye Htwe and Shwe Yinn Mar Oo |date=2008-03-10 |url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no409/n005.htm |accessdate=2010-09-03}}</ref>
==Registration== Students from government high schools and comprehensive schools can register for the examinations internally by the guidelines of school teachers, although students from private boarding schools have to register for the exams externally themselves. Students who attend international English-language schools or other private schools are not eligible to sit for the matriculation exam, nor are they allowed to enroll in Burmese universities.<ref>{{cite news |title=Burma Considers Private Education |newspaper=The Irrawaddy |date=2009-11-18 |url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=17243&page=2 |accessdate=2010-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101005133356/http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=17243&page=2 |archive-date=2010-10-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Over 500,000 students take part in these exams annually, which take place in mid-March each year (for 9 days), with results released at testing sites throughout the country in June.<ref>{{cite news |title=Parents feel the stress of matriculation |newspaper=Myanmar Times |author=Min Zaw |date=2008-03-17 |url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no410/n003.htm |accessdate=2010-09-03 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430045116/http://www.mmtimes.com/no410/n003.htm |archive-date=2011-04-30 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Tested subjects== Students are administered a combination of 6 tests depending on their track: arts, science, and arts and sciences. The subjects offered are [[Burmese language|Myanmar]], [[English language|English]], Mathematics, Chemistry, Physics, Biology, History, Geography, Economics, and Optional Myanmar. Each subject examination is 3 hours long.<ref>{{cite news |title=Timetable of 2010 matriculation examination announced |newspaper=New Light of Myanmar |date=2009-12-19 |url=http://www.myanmar.com/newspaper/nlm/Dec02_19.html |accessdate=2010-09-03}}</ref>
==Exam scores== High marks in a subject garner a distinction known as ''gondu'' ({{my|ဂုဏ်ထူး}}). Students who achieve distinctions in five or more subjects are generally guaranteed placement in one of Myanmar's medical universities, the most selective of universities. In recent years, the combined score of students who receive 5 subject distinctions has been above 500 out of 600. The scores of students at remote testing sites are announced via [[shortwave radio]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Result of matriculation exam on air through Radio Myanmar |newspaper=New Light of Myanmar | author=Aung Shin |date=2010-06-13 |url=http://www.myanmar.com/newspaper/nlm/Jun13_03.html |accessdate=2010-09-03}}</ref> In 2009, 30% of students who participated received passing marks.<ref>{{cite news |title=Results of matriculation exams posted |newspaper=Myanmar Times | author=Aung Shin |date=2010-06-15 |url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no475/n003.htm |accessdate=2009-09-03}}</ref> The pass rate in 2015 was 37.6%, a 7% increase from 2014.<ref name="em">{{cite news|url=http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/local/number-students-pass-university-entrance-exam-distinctions-rises|title=Number of students to pass University Entrance Exam with distinctions rises|date=July 2015|work=Eleven Myanmar|accessdate=18 July 2015}}</ref> In 2018, the national pass rate was 32.82%; the highest pass rate was in [[Mandalay Region]] (38.17%), while the lowest pass rate was in [[Chin State]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://r18h5b54hrdss7tbksbdfhgg2523f34mv.s3.amazonaws.com/pdf/stats/01.pdf|title=၂၀၁၈ ခုနှစ် တက္ကသိုလ်ဝင်စာမေးပွဲ ပြည်နယ်နှင့်တိုင်းဒေသကြီးအလိုက် အောင်ချက်နှင့် ဂုဏ်ထူးဦးရေပြဇယား|last=|first=|date=|website=၂၀၁၈ - တက္ကသိုလ်ဝင် စာမေးပွဲအောင်စာရင်း|access-date=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Education in Burma]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.myanmarexam.org/ Myanmar University Entrance Examination]
{{Undergraduate admission tests}}
[[Category:Education in Myanmar]] [[Category:School examinations]] [[Category:Standardized tests]]

{{refimprove|date=October 2014}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[]] --> The '''Urban Alliance Foundation''' (UA) is a [[501(c)(3)]] nonprofit operating in [[Washington, DC]]. The group works to train youth from under-resourced areas for work and self-sufficiency, through paid [[internship]]s, formal training, case management, and [[mentoring]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theurbanalliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/DCJobPartnerInfo.pdf|title=About Urban Alliance|last=|first=|date=September 2009|website=Urban Alliance|access-date=8 April 2017}}</ref> Urban Alliance was founded in Washington DC in 1996 and has worked with more than 15,000 low-income D.C., Chicago and Baltimore youth.<ref>Presta, John (July 16, 2013), "First Lady Michelle Obama coming to town visiting the Urban Alliance Chicago." Chicago Examiner.</ref>
==History== [[Image:UA Youth.jpg|thumb|200px|UA youth participants at a challenge course in 2005]] UA opened in 1996, after a student attending [[Anacostia]] Senior High School expressed a need for positive job experiences to UA founder Andrew Plepler. Plepler, at that time an Attorney for the U.S. Department of Justice, was visiting the school and asked the students what they needed to succeed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theurbanalliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/DCJobPartnerInfo.pdf|title=About Urban Alliance|last=|first=|date=September 2009|website=Urban Alliance|access-date=8 April 2017}}</ref> Plepler, with the support of Mary and [[Jeff Zients]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/advisory-boards/pmab/members/jeffrey-zients |accessdate=May 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726000726/http://www.whitehouse.gov/administration/advisory-boards/pmab/members/jeffrey-zients |archivedate=July 26, 2012 |title=Jeffrey Zients |website=President's Management Advisory Board}}</ref> placed that student and five of his friends at internships throughout the city during 1996. The program was developed according to the practices implemented by the National Youth Employment Coalition. Specifically, the program aims to establish long-term mentoring relationships with adults, to increases youths’ personal, academic, and financial independence, and support them to meet their increased responsibilities through workshops on [[time management]], [[financial literacy]], and [[conflict resolution]]. The group documents students’ ongoing progress by tracking each internship on a weekly basis and collecting tri-annual ratings from the mentors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theurbanalliance.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/09/DCJobPartnerInfo.pdf|title=About Urban Alliance|last=|first=|date=September 2009|website=Urban Alliance|access-date=8 April 2017}}</ref>
The program continued to work with students at Anacostia Senior High School for the next eight years, providing them with [[youth development]] and employment opportunities. In 2005, UA expanded to recruit students at ten other [[District of Columbia Public Schools]] (DCPS) targeting DCPS seniors who were eligible for a half- day class schedule.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.guidestar.org/profile/52-1938443|title=URBAN ALLIANCE FOUNDATION INC - GuideStar Profile|website=www.guidestar.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-11}}</ref> Monday through Thursday, these students attend school in the morning, work at their job sites in the afternoon and on Fridays attend UA's professional development workshops.
In 2004, UA began working with the [[World Bank]]'s summer internship program. As of 2012, that partnership has resulted in over 170 students finding placement at the World Bank. Students work thirty-two hour weeks as well as attend weekly internship trainings developed by the Bank.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dc-youth-take-on-global-development-158609945.html|title=DC Youth Take on Global Development|last=Alliance|first=The Urban|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-04-08}}</ref> UA also works with organizations such as [[Bank of America]], Marriott, and Morgan Stanley.
In 2008, Urban Alliance expanded to work in the [[Baltimore City Public Schools]]. The organization currently works with nine Baltimore City high schools.<ref>http://www.baltimorecityschools.org/site/default.aspx?PageType=3&ModuleInstanceID=7065&ViewID=047E6BE3-6D87-4130-8424-D8E4E9ED6C2A&RenderLoc=0&FlexDataID=17956&PageID=6776{{dead link|date=October 2014}}</ref> In 2012, Urban Alliance expanded to the [[City of Chicago]]. The organization recruited students from schools such as [[Curie High School]], [[Dunbar Vocational High School]], and Crane Technical Preparatory High School. During the 2012-2013 school year, 71 students from six Chicago public high schools participated. In 2013-2014, the program planned to include 150 students across 13 schools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20130718/south-loop/michelle-obama-tells-students-envision-life-beyond-their-neighborhoods |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130721054913/http://www.dnainfo.com/chicago/20130718/south-loop/michelle-obama-tells-students-envision-life-beyond-their-neighborhoods |archivedate=2013-07-21 |df= }}</ref>
Also in 2012, UA announced a partnership with [[Venture Philanthropy Partners]] (VPP).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://theurbanalliance.org/blog/vpp-and-urban-alliance-announce-a-partnership-to-provide-career-skills-to-youth-in-northern-virginia/|title=VPP and Urban Alliance Announce a Partnership to Provide Career Skills to Youth in Northern Virginia {{!}} Urban Alliance|website=theurbanalliance.org|language=en|access-date=2017-04-11}}</ref> The partnership focused on expanding the foundation's efforts into the suburban areas of Northern Virginia to work with 200 high school students and 70 alumni of the program. UA also works with VPP's youthCONNECT initiative.
==References== <references />
== External links== *{{official website|www.theurbanalliance.org}} *[http://www.nyec.org/ National Youth Employment Coalition]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=April 2016}} {{Infobox school |name = Watkinson School |established = 1881 |type = [[Private school|Private]] |head_name = Headmaster |head = Teri Schrader |city = [[Hartford, Connecticut]] |state = [[Connecticut|CT]] |country = [[United States|USA]] |enrollment = 275 |faculty = 48 |class =7 to 16 students |ratio = 6:1 |colors = White, blue |mascot = Sam the Ram |website = [http://www.watkinson.org/ www.watkinson.org]| }}
'''Watkinson School''' is a [[private school|private]] co-educational independent [[day school]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]], USA. Watkinson is situated on Bloomfield Avenue adjacent to the [[University of Hartford]]. It serves students from 6th through 12th grade. Watkinson also offers a postgraduate option, called The Academy at Watkinson, which allows students who have just graduated from high school to spend an additional year taking courses at Watkinson as well as the University of Hartford.<ref>{{cite web|publisher = Watkinson School|url = http://www.watkinson.org/podium/default.aspx?t=26794|accessdate = 8 January 2006|title = Watkinson School ~ Transition to College}}</ref> Watkinson is the oldest independent school located within the city limits of Hartford.{{citation needed|date=April 2016}}
Currently,{{when|date=April 2016}} Watkinson enrolls 240 students who come from 37 towns all around the [[Greater Hartford]] and [[Pioneer Valley]] area.
Watkinson is a founding member of the [[Coalition of Essential Schools]]. It is one of only five schools to be named a Lead School for this coalition.
==Campus and early school history== {{Infobox NRHP | name = Watkinson Juvenile Asylum and Farm School | nrhp_type = hd | nocat = yes | image = Watkinson School art barn, 2009-08-31.jpg | caption = Watkinson School art barn in 2009 | location= 140, 180 and 190 Bloomfield Avenue, [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] and [[West Hartford, Connecticut]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|47|24|N|72|42|45|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Connecticut#USA | built = {{start date|1881}} | architect = Goodwin, Francis; et al. | architecture = Queen Anne, Colonial Revival | added = March 23, 1995 | area = {{convert|36|acre|ha}} | governing_body = Private | refnum = 95000273<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> }} The organization that became the Watkinson School has its origins in a major bequest of businessman and philanthropist David Watkinson (1778-1857), whose will included provisions for establishing a school for troubled boys. Originally led by noted Hartford educator [[Henry Barnard]], school trustees built Watkinson's bequest to over $200,000 by 1880. In that year, a farm was purchased on Park Street, and the institution was opened as a school and working farm known as the '''Watkinson Juvenile Asylum and Farm School'''. In 1892, under the leadership of Rev. Francis Goodwin, the school leased land on the Prosser Farm at the corner of Albany Street and Bloomfield Avenue, which had been purchased by Goodwin for the Handicraft School, an organization whose leadership was identical to that of the Watkinson School. The Watkinson School facilities were built on this land at the northern end, while those of the Handicraft School were located in its south. The land occupied by the Watkinson School was formally transferred to the school in 1949. The school formally adopted the name "Watkinson School" in 1923.<ref name=NRHP/>
The school campus is located at 140, 180, and 190 Bloomfield Avenue in [[Hartford, Connecticut|Hartford]] and [[West Hartford, Connecticut|West Hartford]]. The complex consists of nine buildings on about {{convert|36|acre|ha}}, most of which (including all of the buildings) is in Hartford. Feringa Hall is the oldest academic building on the campus, built in 1894-5 to a Queen Anne design attributed to Francis Goodwin. Residence houses, originally for the headmaster and his assistant, date to the early 20th century. Frances Goodwin Hall is a two-story brick classroom building with attached gymnasium, built in 1924.<ref name=NRHP>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=95000273}}|title=NRHP nomination for Watkinson Juvenile Asylum and Farm School|publisher=National Park Service|accessdate=2014-12-06}}</ref> The campus was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1995.<ref name=nris/>
==Famous alumni== *[[Johann Smith]] - soccer player with Major League Soccer team [[Kalmar FF]]; as of November 25, 2010, he is a free agent. *[[Richard Plepler]] - CEO of HBO<ref>{{cite news|last=Holson|first=Laura|title=There’s Something About Richard; Richard Plepler of HBO Stands Tall in New York’s Cultural Elite|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/23/fashion/richard-plepler-of-hbo-stands-tall-in-new-yorks-cultural-elite.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=19 February 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=21 September 2012}}</ref>
==See also== *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hartford, Connecticut]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in West Hartford, Connecticut]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.watkinson.org/ Watkinson's web site] * [http://www.watkinson.org/ftpimages/127/download/download_group2335_id132975.pdf Watkinson's literary magazine]

page.title: Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail

revision.text:
{{Infobox book| <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Novels or Wikipedia:WikiProject_Books --> | name = Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail | title_orig = | translator = | image = WildCoverFromAuthorsWebsite.JPG | caption = | author = [[Cheryl Strayed]] | cover_artist = | country = United States of America | language = English | series = | genre = Memoirs; Education and Reference | publisher = [[Alfred A. Knopf|Knopf]] | release_date = March 20, 2012 | media_type = [[Hardcover]], [[Amazon Kindle|Kindle]] Edition, Audio CD, [[Audible.com|Audible]] Audio | pages = 336 pages (hardcover) | isbn = 978-0307592736 | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | italic title = force }}
'''''Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail''''' is a 2012 memoir by [[Americans|American]] author [[Cheryl Strayed]], describing her 1,100-mile hike on the [[Pacific Crest Trail]] in 1995 as a [[journey of self-discovery]]. The book reached No. 1 on the [[New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]], and was the first selection for [[Oprah's Book Club 2.0]].
The [[Wild (2014 film)|film adaptation]] was released in December 2014.
== Plot == ''Wild'' is Cheryl Strayed's memoir of her 1,100 mile solo hike along the [[Pacific Crest Trail]], beginning in the [[Mojave Desert]] and hiking through California and Oregon to the [[Bridge of the Gods (modern structure)|Bridge of the Gods]] into Washington. The book also contains flashbacks to prior life occurrences that led her to begin her journey.<ref name=nyt2>{{cite news|last=Shapiro |first=Dani |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/books/review/wild-a-hiking-memoir-by-cheryl-strayed.html |title=The High Road / Wild, a Hiking Memoir by Cheryl Strayed |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=2012-03-30 |accessdate=2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6ByjZMzMY WebCite archive].</ref><ref name=Oprah201204>{{cite web |url=http://www.oprah.com/spirit/Wild-by-Cheryl-Strayed-Cheryl-Strayed-Interview |title=Cheryl Strayed Hikes Her Way Through Heartbreak in ''Wild'' |publisher=Oprah.com (April 2012 issue of ''O, The Oprah Magazine'') |date=March 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324092418/http://www.oprah.com/spirit/Wild-by-Cheryl-Strayed-Cheryl-Strayed-Interview |archivedate=March 24, 2012 |deadurl=no }} (Originally titled "Inward Bound: Hiking Her Way Through Heartbreak").</ref>
At age 22, Strayed had been devastated by the lung cancer death of her mother at 45. Her stepfather disengaged from Strayed's family, and her brother and sister remained distant. Strayed and her husband divorced, and eventually a lover convinced her to start using [[heroin]].<ref name=nyt2/>
Seeking self-discovery and resolution of her enduring grief and personal challenges, at age 26, Strayed set out on her journey, alone and with no prior hiking experience. ''Wild'' intertwines the stories of Strayed's life before and during the journey, describing her physical challenges and spiritual realizations while on the trail.<ref name=nyt2/>
==Distinctions and recognition== * May 30, 2012: [[Oprah Winfrey]] announced the launch of [[Oprah's Book Club 2.0]] with ''Wild'' as its first selection.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oprah.com/oprahsbookclub/Oprah-Announces-Oprahs-Book-Club-20-Video |title=Oprah Announces Oprah's Book Club 2.0 - Video |publisher=Oprah.com |date=2012-05-30 |accessdate= 2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6ByiPNNiU WebCite archive].</ref> * July 15, 2012: ''Wild'' reached No. 1 on ''The New York Times'' [[The New York Times Best Seller list|Best Seller list]].<ref name=nyt1>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2012-07-15/hardcover-nonfiction/list.html |title=Best Sellers - The New York Times - Hardcover Nonfiction |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6BxKSuZQD WebCite archive].</ref> * December 3, 2012: ''Wild'' was named No. 6 best non-fiction book of 2012 by ''[[The Christian Science Monitor]].''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/Books/2012/1203/15-best-books-of-2012-nonfiction/Wild-From-Lost-to-Found-on-the-Pacific-Crest-Trail-by-Cheryl-Strayed |title=15 best books of 2012 – nonfiction - 'Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail,' by Cheryl Strayed |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=2012-12-03 |accessdate=2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6Cfur9PyF WebCite archive].</ref> * December 4, 2012: ''Wild'' was voted No. 1 book of 2012 in the "Memoir and Autobiography" category in the "[[Goodreads]] Choice Awards 2012."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goodreads.com/choiceawards/best-books-2012 |title=Best Books 2012 — Goodreads Choice Awards |publisher=Goodreads.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6CfUyIKNh WebCite archive].</ref> * January 2013: ''Wild'' was selected as [[Book of the Week]] on [[BBC Radio 4]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01phf4f Book of the Week - ''Wild''] bbc.co.uk</ref> * 2013: ''Wild'' spent 52 weeks on the [[NPR]] Hardcover Nonfiction Bestseller List.<ref name=NPRbooksWildProfile>{{cite web |title=Wild / Awards and Recognition |url=https://www.npr.org/books/titles/148682362/wild-from-lost-to-found-on-the-pacific-crest-trail |publisher=NPR Arts & Life > Books |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VgO02Pj2 |archivedate=January 18, 2015 |accessdate=January 18, 2015}}</ref> * April 2013: For ''Wild,'' Strayed received the Reader's Choice Award in the 2013 [[Oregon Book Award]]s.<ref name=OPB20130412>{{cite web |last1=Kin |first1=John |title=2013 Oregon Book Awards Winners Announced |url=http://www.opb.org/artsandlife/article/2013-oregon-book-awards-winners-announced/ |publisher=OPB (Oregon Public Broadcasting) |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VgPVlwPq |archivedate=January 18, 2015 |date=April 12, 2013}}</ref> * By August 2015: The book had been translated into thirty languages.<ref name=OregonLive20150825>{{cite web |last1=Richard |first1=Terry |title=Pacific Crest Trail Days at hand for Cascade Locks |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/travel/index.ssf/2015/08/pacific_crest_trail_days_at_ha.html |publisher=''Oregon Live'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151231105620/http://www.oregonlive.com/travel/index.ssf/2015/08/pacific_crest_trail_days_at_ha.html |archivedate=December 31, 2015 |date=August 25, 2015 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
==Film== {{main|Wild (2014 film)}} By the time the book was published, actress [[Reese Witherspoon]]'s film company, Pacific Standard, had optioned ''Wild'' for film rights.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hallett |first=Alison |url=http://blogtown.portlandmercury.com/BlogtownPDX/archives/2012/03/15/cheryl-strayeds-wild-optioned-by-reese-witherspoon |title=Cheryl Strayed's Wild Optioned by Reese Witherspoon | Blogtown, PDX |publisher=Blogtown.portlandmercury.com |date=2012-03-15 |accessdate=2012-12-24}} [https://www.webcitation.org/6C3xEmHlC WebCite archive].</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Reese Witherspoon Set For Nick Hornby’s Book Adaptation ‘Wild’ For Fox Searchlight|url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/reese-witherspoon-to-star-in-wild-book-adaptation-for-fox-searchlight/|accessdate=2013-07-17 |newspaper=deadline.com |date=2013-07-16}}</ref> Witherspoon portrayed Strayed in the 2014 film ''[[Wild (2014 film)|Wild]],'' which was written by [[Nick Hornby]] and directed by [[Jean-Marc Vallée]].
==Reception== In ''[[The New York Times]],'' [[Dwight Garner (critic)|Dwight Garner]] wrote that "the lack of ease in (Strayed's) life made her fierce and funny; she hammers home her hard-won sentences like a box of nails," adding that the memoir reflected a "too infrequent sight: that of a writer finding her voice, and sustaining it, right in front of your eyes."<ref name=NYTimes20120327>{{cite web |last=Garner |first=Dwight |title=The Tracks of an Author’s, and a Reader’s Tears / ‘Wild’ by Cheryl Strayed, a Walkabout of Reinvention |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/28/books/wild-by-cheryl-strayed-a-walkabout-of-reinvention.html?pagewanted=all |website=The New York Times |archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/6VACbFGO1 |archivedate=December 28, 2014 |date=March 27, 2012}}</ref>
In ''[[The New York Times]],'' [[Dani Shapiro]] called the book "spectacular... at once a breathtaking adventure tale and a profound meditation on the nature of grief and survival, ... both a literary and human triumph."<ref name=NYTimes20120330/> Shapiro wrote that unlike many parallel-arc stories, Strayed's two parallel narratives—the challenging hike itself and the difficult life events that preceded it—are delivered in perfect balance.<ref name=NYTimes20120330/> According to Shapiro, the memoir did not overdramatize its events, but followed a "powerful, yet understated, imperative to understand (their) meaning," allowing readers "to feel how her actions and her internal struggles intertwine, and appreciate the lessons she finds embedded in the natural world."<ref name=NYTimes20120330>{{cite web |last=Shapiro |first=Dani |title=The High Road / ‘Wild,’ a Hiking Memoir by Cheryl Strayed |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/01/books/review/wild-a-hiking-memoir-by-cheryl-strayed.html?pagewanted=all |website=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6VAEfncFp |archivedate=December 28, 2014 |date=March 30, 2012}}</ref>
In ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]],'' Melanie Rehak began by contrasting ''Wild'' with the 2006 memoir ''[[Eat, Pray, Love]]''—whose story was "pleasant, mild, romantic, and completely lacking urgency" and in which everything would work out.<ref name=Slate20120303/> In contrast, ''Wild'' was said to be "crammed with... passages of vicious discomfort" and was carried by a voice that was "fierce, billowing with energy, precise."<ref name=Slate20120303/> Crediting the years that passed between Strayed's 1995 hike and her 2012 memoir, Rehak wrote that Strayed had "fine control" over "unfathomable, enormous experiences" and never wrote "from a place of desperation in the kind of semi-edited purge state that has marred so many true stories."<ref name=Slate20120303>{{cite web |last1=Rehak |first1=Melanie |title=Trail of Tears |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2012/03/cheryl_strayed_s_wild_reviewed_.single.html |publisher=''Slate'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303181008/http://www.slate.com/articles/arts/books/2012/03/cheryl_strayed_s_wild_reviewed_.single.html |archivedate=March 3, 2012 |date=March 3, 2012 |deadurl=no}}</ref>
By the time of the film ''[[Wild (2014 film)|Wild]]'s'' release, in December 2014 [[A.O. Scott]] wrote in ''[[The New York Times]]'' that Strayed's memoir was "already a classic of wilderness writing and modern feminism."<ref name=NYTimes20141202>{{cite web |last1=Scott |first1=A. O. |title=Walking With Solitude, and Her Baggage / ‘Wild’ Stars Reese Witherspoon |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/03/movies/wild-stars-reese-witherspoon.html |publisher=''The New York Times'' |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209200335/http://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/03/movies/wild-stars-reese-witherspoon.html |archivedate=December 9, 2014 |date=December 2, 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.oprah.com/spirit/Quotes-from-Wild-by-Cheryl-Strayed-Wild-Quotes The Most Inspiring Quotes from ''Wild''] at [[Oprah Winfrey|Oprah.com]] * [http://www.cherylstrayed.com/wild_108676.htm ''Wild's'' page] on the author's website (includes pictures) <small>([https://www.webcitation.org/6C3yv3dwO WebCite archive])</small>

The '''Witherby Memorial Lecture''' is an academic lectureship awarded by the [[British Trust for Ornithology]] annually since 1968.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bto.org/about-bto/accounts/witherby-memorial-lectures|title=Witherby Memorial Lectures - BTO - British Trust for Ornithology|website=www.bto.org}}</ref>

[[File:First Iranian women university.jpg|thumb|Iranian women at the first female university including [[:en:Mehrangiz Manouchehrian|Mehrangiz Manouchehrian]] (senator), [[:en:Shams-ol-Molouk Mosahab|Shams-ol-Molouk Mosahab]] (senator) and [[:en:Bardrolmolouk Bamdad|Bardrolmolouk Bamdad]].|alt=Iranian women attending the First Women's University in Iran]] Formal education for women in Iran began in 1907 with the establishment of the first primary school for girls.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Esfehani|first=qouhi|date=2014|title=Iranian Women: One Step Forward, Two Steps Back|url=|journal=Middle Eastern Studies / Ortadogu Etütleri|volume=5|issue=2|pages=36, 38, 39, 40|doi=|pmid=|ref=qouhi}}</ref> Education held an important role in Iranian society, especially as the nation began a period of modernization under the authority of [[Reza Shah|Reza Shah Pahlavi]] in the early 20th century when the number of women's schools began to grow. By mid-century, legal reforms granting women the right to vote and raising the minimum age for marriage offered more opportunities for women to pursue education outside the home.<ref name=":0" /> After periods of imposed restrictions, women's educational attainment continued its rise through the Islamification of education following the Iranian Revolution of 1979, peaking in the years following radical changes in the curriculum and composition of classrooms.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Mehran|first=Golnar|date=2003-08-01|title=The Paradox of Tradition and Modernity in Female Education in the Islamic Republic of Iran|url=http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/doi/10.1086/378248|journal=Comparative Education Review|volume=47|issue=3|pages=269–286|doi=10.1086/378248|issn=0010-4086}}</ref> By 1989, women dominated the entrance examinations for college attendance.<ref name=":12"/>
Women's participation in education has not slowed despite efforts to impose restrictions on the increasingly female-dominated educational sphere. The changes in women's education have split into increased usage and dominance of the opportunities available to women, and the imposition of strict requirements governing their role in education, including gender-segregated classes, Islamic dress, and the channeling of women into "feminine" majors that prevent the pursuit of certain careers.<ref name=":2" />
== History of education for women in Iran ==
The nature of education for Iranian women changed significantly from the period leading up to the Iranian Revolution when compared to the imposition of restrictions following it. Despite the various obstacles for women entering an educational setting, they manage to comprise the majority of college attendees and outperform their male peers on university admissions tests as well as in graduation rates.
=== Pre-Iranian Revolution ===
At the beginning of the 20th century education for women expanded slowly, with enrollment of female students in the 1922 academic year totaling just over 7200 students compared with 35,000 of their male peers.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Iravani|first=Mohammad Reza|date=2011|title=Women's Education, Employment and Unemployment in Iran|url=|journal=J. Basic. Appl. Sci. Res.|volume=1|pages=2965–2970|doi=|pmid=|number=12}}</ref> In 1935, women first experienced the secularization of Iran's educational system when the University of Tehran was established.<ref name=":12"/> As the nation's secularization created demand for professionally trained students, women were encouraged to attend schools. Education became a social norm and a marker of achievement in Iranian society.
On the eve of the Iranian Revolution, in 1976-77, 40 percent of secondary school enrollment was female.<ref name=":2" /> These numbers largely reflect the upper echelon of Iranian society, as women who were a part of an ethnic minority or from rural areas of Iran were largely excluded from these educational reforms.
=== Education from Iranian Revolution, 1979-1989 ===
The [[Iranian Revolution]] of March 1979 ushered in a period of conservative leadership that altered the role and conception of the new model female in Iranian society.<ref name=":0" /> The period was characterized by the retraction of previously passed laws reforming women's status in the home, and the institution in its place of family and civil law based in notions of patriarchy.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Rezai-Rashti|first=Goli M.|last2=Moghadam|first2=Valentine M.|date=2011-10-13|title=Women and higher education in Iran: What are the implications for employment and the "marriage market"?|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11159-011-9217-9|journal=International Review of Education|language=en|volume=57|issue=3–4|pages=419–441|doi=10.1007/s11159-011-9217-9|issn=0020-8566}}</ref>
The newly enacted [[Constitution of the Islamic Republic of Iran]] stated the importance of women's economic and social well-being, yet did not guarantee the right to educational opportunities.<ref name=":2" /> Instead, the new regime of religious authority cracked down on women's participation in education, barring coeducation.<ref name=":2" /> Immediately following the Revolution, universities and many high schools were shut down, not to be reopened for another 3 years. During this time many female faculty were excused from their positions and many women lost their jobs. This included all female judges as well as women who held positions of authority in the government.<ref name=":3" />
Upon reopening of schools and under the leadership of [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Ayatollah Khomein<nowiki/>i]], educational curriculum was altered to reflect a new focus on Islamic values. Women were depicted wearing a veil in textbooks, appearing in social studies books as managers of the home and offering guidance on Islam and schoolwork. Men were depicted as providers for the family's needs.<ref name=":2" /> Some women did appear in pursuit of farming or factory work, working in hospitals and in schools in these textbooks, mostly in conformity with a gender stereotype of feminine work.<ref name=":2" /> Because of this, Iran became a sexist place. [[File:Pmiokl.jpg|thumb|Iranian women taking the university entrance exam.|alt=Women sitting for the Konkur, the university entrance exam]] Textbooks and curriculum remained uniform across genders, though the Ministry of Education's "Study of Professions" textbooks differentiated between "male" and "female" specializations and were distributed according to gender.<ref name=":2" /> In 1982, gender stereotyped work was institutionalized by the Ministry of Education's introduction of ''KAr va Danesh'', an experiential cooperative day in which students were excused from school to work in various occupations. For females, these experiences consisted of workshops focused on topics such as nutrition, child rearing, cooking, and health.<ref name=":2" />
Course restrictions in higher education also began under the authority of [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Religious leader Khomeini]], in which men and women were each barred from studying certain majors. Women were excluded from studying veterinary science, animal husbandry, geology, and natural resources, while men were precluded from subjects such as fashion design, obstetrics, and mid-wifery.<ref name=":12"/> Of 108 mathematics and computer science majors, women were only permitted to study 43. The government also established quotas for certain specializations, capping the number of women who could pursue specified majors to ensure against the domination of women in these subjects.<ref name=":3" /> To comply with the segregation of sexes in schooling and employment, the segregation of subjects led to the founding of a women's only medical school so that female patients could seek treatment from a female physician.<ref name=":2" />
Out of fear that single women may be corrupted by external society, state scholarships to study abroad were also restricted, offered to male students and married women only.<ref name=":2" /> The "Sponsorship for Foreign Students Act" additionally required that married women who received the scholarship be accompanied by their husbands.<ref name=":2" />
Beginning in 1980, female faculty and students were directed to wear Islamic dress by the Ministry of Education. The institution of veiling throughout Iran in 1981 extended the compulsion to women beginning at 6 years of age. At this time many schools limited teachers to instruct only same-gendered students.<ref name=":12"/>
=== Khomeini to Khatami, 1989-2005 ===
In 1989, the First Economic, Social, and Cultural Development Plan of the Islamic Republic of Iran, 1989-1993, offered improvement in women's educational opportunities and involvement in social and economic life as key targets for the incoming administration.<ref name=":2" /> Following the death of Khomeini in 1989, President [[Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani|Rafsanjani]] began a process of scaling back restrictions on women's education.<ref name=":3" /> Hurdles to education still existed, with the majority of Iranian women married by the age of 19 at the start of the 1990s.<ref name=":4" /> The situation was more dire for rural female students, with half of female Iranians living outside urban areas remaining uneducated.<ref name=":4" />
Progress began to be made toward alleviating some of these restrictions in the 1990s. Quotas restricting the number of women who could study particular fields were eliminated while the Women's Cultural and Social Council, an institution headed by Iranian women who held influential positions in Iran, began studying the effects continued restrictions had on the Iranian economy. This led to a lifting of all remaining quotas or bans on studying particular fields, completed in 1993.<ref name=":3" /> By the 1990s many of the restrictions imposed on majors were also lifted, offering women more opportunities to pursue a degree in fields such as veterinary science that were banned under the Khomeini government. More women beyond the few, urban elite that initially enrolled in higher education began to attend school under its Islamic form, no longer hesitant about sending their children to institutions taught by men.<ref name=":12"/>
Educational opportunities continued through the rule of [[Mohammad Khatami]], who served as President of Iran from 1997-2005. Khatami viewed the home as the proper setting for an Iranian woman, yet did not seek to exclude her from participation in the public sphere.<ref name=":2" /> Noting the increasing dominance of women in higher education, Khatami stated that though the increase was concerning, he did not wish to create obstacles in order to reduce this participation.<ref name=":6" /> Khatami called for an opening of majors and specialities for women in universities and an end to the quota system.<ref name=":6" />
At the beginning of Khatami's presidency, over 95 percent girls in Iran attended elementary school.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Women and Politics in the Islamic Republic of Iran: Action and Reaction|last=Vakil|first=Sanam|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing USA|year=2011|isbn=1441105166|location=|pages=}}</ref> In 1997-98, 38.2 percent of Iranian women enrolled in higher education.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Women, Power and Politics in 21st Century Iran|last=Povey|first=Tara|last2=Rostami-Povey|first2=Elaheh|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|year=2012|isbn=1409402053|location=|pages=42}}</ref> This number rose to 47.2 percent by 2000.<ref name=":6" /> As female enrollment in schooling continued to climb, the segregation of the sexes in academic specialization continued to persist through the end of the 1990s. In the 1998-99 academic year, males dominated enrollment in math-physics and technical fields with 58 and 71 percent of the enrolled class of secondary school students. Women disproportionately comprised the humanities and experimental sciences field with 61 percent enrollment.<ref name=":2" /> Gender specialization continued through university level where the fields of basic sciences, medical sciences, and arts were studied by a majority of women, and agriculture and veterinary science, engineering, and humanities were pursued mostly by men.<ref name=":2" /> Overall, however, the decade was characterized by a three-fold increase in female enrollment in higher education.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Kurzman|first=Charles|date=2008-01-01|title=A Feminist Generation in Iran?|jstor=25597464|journal=Iranian Studies|volume=41|issue=3|pages=297–321|doi=10.1080/00210860801981260}}</ref>
At the turn of the 21st century the government continued to scale back restrictions. By 2000, the government supported the establishment of a Women's Studies course to be offered for graduate level study of topics including [[Women's rights in Iran|women's rights]].<ref name=":6" /> A 2001 report on women's status in Iran published by his office emphasized the goal of improving educational materials for women to reflect their modern role in society, including the counseling of high school students toward specializations that were traditionally dominated by men.<ref name=":2" /> In 2001, the government also authorized the use of the "Sponsorship for Foreign Students Act" supplement for single women to study abroad, a change from the former restriction. Single women could avail themselves of the funds to pursue higher education in foreign institutions, with the consent of their fathers.<ref name=":2" /> 2001 is also the year that female enrollment in university-level education exceeded that of men, showing their continued dominance of education.<ref name=":3" />
The statistics of the Khatami presidency show the slow rise of female participation in education. In 2002, women dominated the results of its national college entrance examination, comprising 62 percent of passing students.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Shavarini|first=Mitra K.|date=2005-01-01|title=The Feminisation of Iranian Higher Education|jstor=25054545|journal=International Review of Education / Internationale Zeitschrift für Erziehungswissenschaft / Revue Internationale de l'Education|volume=51|issue=4|pages=329–347, 331, 333, 334, 335}}</ref> Women pursuing teaching positions in higher education also made gains during this period, holding nearly half of all assistant professorships at universities, nearly double that held a decade before.<ref name=":3" /> The number of women accepted into tenured-track and full-time professorships in 2001-02 remained low at 17.3 percent as it was not nearly as proportionate to the number of educated women in Iranian society.<ref name=":3" />
=== Ahmadinejad Era, 2005-2013 ===
Many of the reforms achieved earlier in Rasfanjani and Khatami's presidencies were eroded with the election of [[Mahmoud Ahmadinejad]] in 2005. In 2006, the average woman in Iran attended school for nine years.<ref name=":3" /> At the start of his presidency in 2007-08, women's gains in education permeated every level, composing 44 percent of students pursuing associate degrees, 55 percent of bachelor's degree students, 43 percent of master's degree students, and a high 58 percent of students pursuing a professional doctorate.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Mehran|first=Golnar|date=2009-01-01|title="Doing And Undoing Gender": Female Higher Education In The Islamic Republic Of Iran|jstor=40608077|journal=International Review of Education / Internationale Zeitschrift für Erziehungswissenschaft / Revue Internationale de l'Education|volume=55|issue=5/6|pages=541–559|doi=10.1007/s11159-009-9145-0}}</ref> Women also dominated 6 of the 7 academic fields offered at university level, save for engineering, comprising the majority of students studying veterinary sciences, basic sciences, human sciences, medical sciences, agriculture and the arts.<ref name=":7" />
With the former rise of participation by women in education and the reduction of artificially created obstacles to their success in pursuing studies, conservative forces in the Iranian government became alarmed at the erosion of traditional notions of women's role in the home and the competition in the labor market with educated men for whom work outside the home was essential.<ref name=":6" /> The government took action, with Ahmadinejad appointing a religious cleric as the Chancellor of the secular [[University of Tehran|Tehran University]] in November 2005.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Razavi|first=Reza|date=2009-01-01|title=The Cultural Revolution in Iran, with Close Regard to the Universities, and its Impact on the Student Movement|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/00263200802547586|journal=Middle Eastern Studies|volume=45|issue=1|pages=1–17|doi=10.1080/00263200802547586|issn=0026-3206}}</ref> In 2006, the Ministry of Health and Education imposed a quota system on particular majors and specialities and restricted enrollment of women to universities located in their hometowns.<ref name=":6" /> It also instituted the gender segregation of higher education.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Power, Islam, and Political Elite in Iran. A Study on the Iranian Political Elite from Khomeini to Ahmadinejad|last=Rakel|first=Eva|publisher=BRILL|year=2008|isbn=9047425081|location=|pages=140}}</ref>
The response from students to what was perceived as the attempt to turn secular universities into religious institutions were protests demanding the preservation of civil liberties, such as the freedom of speech. Conservative politicians demanded, in turn, a crackdown on the "westernization" of secular education and an imposition of Islamic philosophy. The [[Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei|Supreme Leader]]'s spokesman for higher education, Hojatoleslam Mohammadian, and the Minister of Science and Higher Education, [[Mohammad Mehdi Zahedi]], both called for the Islamization of universities, while Mohammadian also stated his opposition to women pursuing certain studies in higher education.<ref name=":8" />
In 2009 Ahmadinejad's pursuit of the further de-feminization of education led to the establishment of the "Special Council for the Development and Promotion of Humanities."<ref name=":3" /> Iran's [[Supreme Council of the Cultural Revolution]] oversaw this effort, in which seven appointees were responsible for infusing humanities discipline with Islamic principles.<ref name=":3" />
==== 2010-11 Restrictions ====
In 2010, Iran again adopted a quota system to limit the number of women able to enter university education.<ref name=":9">{{Cit journal|last=Haeri|first=Shahla|date=May 1, 2013|title=Comparative And International Perspectives On The 'End Of Men': No End In Sight: Politics, Paradox, And Gender Policies In Iran|url=|journal=Boston University Law Review|volume=93|page=1049|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> Iran imposed restrictions on a dozen social studies courses, including women's studies and human rights, on the grounds that "The content of the current courses in the 12 subjects is not in harmony with religious fundamentals and they are based on Western schools of thought."<ref name="AP4">{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3974198,00.html|title=Iran restricts social sciences seen as 'Western'|first=Associated Press|date=24 October 2010|newspaper=Associated Press|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref>
In 2011, universities began to announce new restrictions on entry to female students. Whereas previously students who scored highest on the previously gender-neutral university entrance exam, the ''Konkur'', were placed in the best university programs across the country, universities now barred females from enrollment in over 70 specializations.<ref name=":9" /> The practical result was to concentrate more women in local universities closer to their homes, and farther from the urban, more secular universities they were otherwise qualified to attend.<ref name=":9" />
===== January 2011 Allameh Tabatabai University announcement ===== In January 2011, the president of [[Allameh Tabatabai University]] in [[Tehran]], [[Sadreddin Shariati]], announced that subjects with large numbers of students would be split by gender. Prior to this, university libraries and canteens were already segregated. It was claimed that the Iranian public had already been requesting gender segregation in education in some highly religious areas and in the capital; also, such segregation was said to already be in progress in a number of other Iranian universities. Senior cleric [[Hojatoleslam Mohammad Mohamadian]] pushed for segregated classes in 2006, and again in 2009; other governmental requests to allow segregation date back over 15 years.<ref name="UWN1">{{cite news|url=http://www.universityworldnews.com/article.php?story=20110204224833806|title=IRAN: Growing separation of genders in universities|author1=Sharma, Yojana |author2=Raeis, Shaya |lastauthoramp=yes |date=6 February 2011|newspaper=University World News|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref>
==== August 2012 Course Ban ==== {{POV|date=May 2016}} On 20 August 2012, an announcement was made by Iran's [[Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)|Ministry of Science, Research and Technology]] that 36 universities in [[Iran]] would be cutting 77 fields of study from the female curriculum, making them male-only fields. The fields chosen include most sciences and engineering, among others. The curriculum change was set to be implemented for the 2013 school year and the fields of study limitations for women have been added to the university "leaflets".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://rt.com/news/iran-women-university-ban-171/|title=Male-order education: Iran bars women from 77 university courses|date=21 August 2012|newspaper=[[RT (TV network)|Russia Today]]|author=[[Staff writer]]|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> Universities like the [[Oil Industry University]] have completely barred women from attending, citing the "lack of employer demand".<ref name="hdn22">{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/iran-bans-women-from-77-university-majors-including-engineering-physics-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=28325&NewsCatID=352|title=Iran bans women from 77 university majors, including engineering, physics|date=22 August 2012|newspaper=[[Hurriyet Daily News]]|location=Istanbul|author=[[Staff writer]]|accessdate=22 August 2012}}</ref>
The announcement came soon after the release of statistics showing that women were graduating in far higher numbers than men from Iranian universities and were scoring overall better than men, especially in the sciences.<ref name="Telegraph2">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/iran/9487761/Anger-as-Iran-bans-women-from-universities.html|title=Anger as Iran bans women from universities|date=20 August 2012|publisher=The Telegraph|accessdate=August 24, 2012|author=Tait, Robert}}</ref>
This reasoning was echoed by [[Isfahan University]], which stated that from those that obtained mining engineering degrees "98 percent of female graduates ended up jobless."<ref name="Telegraph2"/> The disciplines related to agriculture were also regarded as "unfit" for female students.<ref name="hdn22" /> Therefore, as a consequence of this move, women may not become engineers, nuclear physicists, archaeologists, business graduates and computer scientists in Iran.<ref name="hdn22" /> Additionally, they are also banned from attending the departments of English literature, translation and hotel management.<ref name="hdn22" /> Another reason given was that because of a shortage of available female dormitories, attendance had to be lowered. A comparison was made, however, to the fact that [[nursing]] was made a female-only degree in the same announcement.<ref name="LAT2">{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/world_now/2012/08/iranian-universities-female-students.html|title=Iranian universities shut female students out of dozens of fields|date=20 August 2012|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|author1=Ramin Mostaghim |author2=Emily Alpert |lastauthoramp=yes |accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref>
The possibility of fields of study restrictions was first reported by the [[Mehr News Agency]] on 6 August 2012. The news followed the release of the year's entrance exam scores, showing that 60 percent of university attendees are women,<ref name="NYT2">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/20/world/middleeast/20iht-educbriefs20.html?_r=1|title=Universities in Iran Put Limits on Women's Options|date=20 August 2012|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|author=Zakiyyah Wahab|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> along with test scores of the past few years showing women largely outperforming men. This included 52 percent of university graduates and 68 percent of science degree graduates being women.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-21/iran-barring-women-from-atomic-oil-fields-draws-rebuke.html|title=Iran Barring Women From Atomic, Oil Fields Draws Rebuke|date=21 August 2012|newspaper=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|author=Jonathan Tirone|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> These results have caused concern among the senior clerics of the country, who became worried about the "social side-effects of rising educational standards among women, including declining birth and marriage rates".<ref name="Telegraph2"/>
[[Amnesty International]] reported that in April 2012, university security personnel at the Roudehen Branch of Islamic [[Azad University]] beat female students who were not complying with [[hijab]] (Islamic dress) standards.<ref name="AI1">{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/mde13/033/2012/en/|title=Amnesty International Joint Public Statement|first=Amnesty International|publisher=Amnesty International|accessdate=26 August 2012}}</ref> They also claimed reports of quotas restricting women’s admission to specific university programs ("designed to reduce women’s access to specific fields of study") implemented by the [[Ministry of Science, Research and Technology (Iran)|Ministry of Science, Research and Technology]]. Such restrictions on women’s educational choices were said to violate the prohibition on discrimination and Iran’s obligations under [[international law]].<ref name="AI1" />
===== Responses ===== [[Seyed Abolfazl Hassani]], a senior Iranian education official, stated in defense of the announcement that, "Some fields are not very suitable for women’s nature, such as agricultural machinery or mining, partly because of the hard work involved in them."<ref name="LAT2"/><ref name="NYT2"/> The policy change was criticized by some Iranian parliamentarians, such as [[Mohammad-Mehdi Zahedi]], head of the Iranian parliament’s education and research committee. However, [[Kamran Daneshjoo]], the science and higher education minister, gave a "guarded response" to the news, saying that the universities would have to state a reason, but also supported the change by explaining that "90 percent of degrees remain open to both sexes and that single-gender courses were needed to create 'balance'." Zahedi said in response that Daneshjoo is "expected to present himself to parliament to explain this policy".<ref name="Telegraph2"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theinternational.org/articles/235-tensions-in-the-iranian-leadership-over-e|title=Tensions in the Iranian Leadership Over Excluding Women from Universities|date=August 27, 2012|newspaper=The International|author=[[Staff writer]]|accessdate=August 27, 2012}}</ref>
Iranian [[Nobel Peace Prize]] winner and human rights activist [[Shirin Ebadi]] wrote to the [[United Nations]] in protest of the restrictions, stating that the Iranian government is "trying to limit the active presence of women in society". She has asked for the issue to be added to "Iran's human rights dossier". The letter was then forwarded to UN special rapporteur for Iran Ahmad Shaheed and to the UN [[High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Navanethem Pillay]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.payvand.com/news/12/aug/1176.html|title=Nobel laureate calls on UN to protect Iranian women|date=21 August 2012|newspaper=[[Radio Zamaneh]]|author=Staff writer|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref> Ebadi also added that the purpose of this policy change is to reduce the number of female university attendees to below 50 percent, down from the current 65 percent .<ref name="Telegraph2" /> On 22 September 2012, [[Human Rights Watch]] urged Iran to reverse the new policy, claiming that such restrictions are a violation of the international right to education for everyone without discrimination.<ref name="CT12">{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-iran-womenbre88l03l-20120922,0,6158083.story|title=Lift restrictions on women's education, rights group tells Iran|last=Torbati|first=Yeganeh|date=22 September 2012|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=22 September 2012}}</ref>
=== Rouhani Era, 2013-Present === When [[Hassan Rouhani]] took control of the Presidency in 2013, there was hope that he would usher in a radical shift in Iranian society toward equal women's rights.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/washwire/2015/11/17/hassan-rouhanis-womens-rights-conundrum/|title=Hassan Rouhani’s Women’s Rights Conundrum|last=Esfandiari|first=Haleh|date=17 November 2015|work=|access-date=|via=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Hopes that he would scale back quota use and institute more lenient reforms have not been fully realized, with the [[United Nations Special Rapporteur|UN Special Rapporteur]] noting in a 2015 report that significant discrimination against women still persists in the political and economic spheres, overshadowing the gains made in education.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=A/70/352|title=Report of the Secretary-General on the situation of human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran|website=www.un.org|access-date=2016-05-19}}</ref> The Special Rapporteur also noted that despite 14 recommendations made to alleviate the obstacles currently preventing equal gender attainment in the educational sphere, the Rouhani government rejected consideration of all of them.<ref name=":1" />
While the vast majority of Iranian students who attend secondary school do not go on to study at a university, 42 percent of women who take the university entrance exams continue on to higher education, compared to 29 percent of males.<ref name=":12" /> The state of literacy and educational attainment among ethnic minority females is also poor when compared to urban, non-minority peers, as they are not forced to attend school and often enter marriage at an early age.<ref name=":1" />
The dual nature of female participation in education is not yet reflected in their role in the economy, where 20-25 percent of educated women are able to find work.<ref name=":12" />
== Alternative Schooling Options for Women in Iran ==
=== Adult Literacy Programs ===
In addition to formal education, women in Iran may enroll in literacy programs.<ref name=":2" /> These programs target women, offering basic training in simple math, reading, and writing. In the 1990s, women composed over two-thirds of enrollees in these programs.<ref name=":2" /> This may have contributed to the steep rise in female literacy rates in Iran in the 1990s, which increased twenty-percent from 1987 to 1997.<ref name=":2" />
=== Religious Schools ===
Religious schools have also become an educational option for Iranian women, and the rise in the institution of "female seminaries" to 280 as of 2010 shows their increasing use as an academic pursuit.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Sakurai|first=Keiko|date=November 2012|title=Shi‘ite Women’s Seminaries (howzeh-ye ‘elmiyyeh-ye khahran) in Iran: Possibilities and Limitations|url=|journal=Iranian Studies|volume=45|doi=10.1080/00210862.2012.726846 |pmid=|pages=727–744}}</ref> The popularity stems from the infusion of religion into Iran post-revolution, when Ayatollah Khomeini called for the establishment of [[Jamiat al-Zahra|Jami‘at al-Zahra]] in 1984, the first female seminary in Iran.<ref name=":11"/> The institution, a consolidation of smaller religious schools, offers enrollees the chance to earn anything from high school diplomas to doctoral degrees.<ref name=":11" /> Women must apply to enroll in the institutions, where only 7,000 women were accepted from a field of over 25,000 applicants in the 2010 academic year.<ref name=":11"/>
Seminaries have served as an alternative to higher education when female applicants are denied admission, either as a result of academic success or the quota system employed by public universities.<ref name=":11" />
=== Other schooling ===
Newly married Iranian women must attend government-mandated family planning classes.<ref name=":2" /> Information on health and birth control use is included in these programs.<ref name=":2" />
== Role of Education in Iran == Though education has been dominated in many fields by females, especially at the university level, it has not enabled women to enter the work force in comparative numbers.<ref name=":3" /> Aside from having an empowering aspect for women, some scholars note increased schooling has yet to result in paid employment increases or roles in authoritative positions of employment.<ref name=":3" /> While female participation in the paid economy was shown to increase by a third after the Iranian Revolution, the seemingly optimistic figure was attributed more so to the continued employment of women already in the labor force rather than an increase in newly graduated women successfully entering it.<ref name=":5" /> Whereas 23.5 million men held paid positions in the Iranian economy in 2006, for instance, merely 3.5 million Iranian women obtained similar positions, or 20 percent of the labor force pool.<ref name=":3" />
The increase in educational opportunities has also not correlated with an increase in the number of educated women entering decision-making positions in government or the private economy. Women are largely absent from high-level full-time professorship positions or as heads of institutions of higher educations, a reality made more difficult by the low enrollment rate of women at the master's and specialized doctorate levels of education that are necessary for positions in university-level positions.<ref name=":7" /> Some scholars have argued that education has contributed to female self-empowerment, giving women a task to achieve that is outside the home even if it does lead to viable employment.
Survey evidence indicates that young educated Iranian women view education as important or very important to a female in Iranian society, more so than other members of Iranian society.<ref name=":5" /> More of these educated youth also believe, more so than their non-educated and older female compatriots, that their daughters should marry following attendance of an institution of higher education.<ref name=":5" /> The education of Iranian women has correspondingly led to a delayed entry into marriage, with non-educated females more than half as likely to be married by the time they turn 22 years old than educated peers.<ref name=":5" /> Education is also shown to contribute to the delayed start of having a family, with the majority of educated women having their first child by the age of 24, 4 years later than non-educated women in Iran.<ref name=":5" />

{{Refimprove|date=November 2008}} The '''Youth Empowerment Scheme''', or '''YES''', is a charity in [[Belfast]] that offers a mentoring service to children between 11 and 14 years old.
==History== YES was established in 2001 by participants on the [[Washington Ireland Program]] including Chris Johnston, Ryan Moffett, Sarah Quinlan and Andrea Erskine and was based on [[Teamwork for Tomorrow]], a similar scheme run by students at [[Notre Dame University]], [[United States]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wiprogram.org/AlumniUpdate.cfm |title=Alumni Updates |publisher=Washington Ireland Program}}</ref>
In 2004 YES was awarded the BT Link Award for Challenge with the University of Ulster.
==Approach== The Youth Empowerment Scheme aims at empowering the young people of Belfast and encouraging them to be active citizens in their city. It holds that [[youth mentoring]] can provide young people with positive role models, support and encouragement, and is thus the most effective way of helping them reach their fullest potential as citizens and productive members of society.
YES aims to promote the social inclusion of young people of ethnic, religious, educational and social economic diversity. To contribute to the creation of a tolerant, pluralist society in Belfast, free from racism, sectarianism and anti-Semitism, the Youth Empowerment Scheme runs weekly workshops that explain and celebrate the diversity of cultures in the city. In 2005 a project entitled 'Gaining Voice' culminated in the release of a short film written and produced by the young participants in the Scheme. It took the form of a political broadcast and highlighted issues of concern to young people, such as peer pressure, bullying and racism.
==Operations== The Youth Empowerment Scheme is run primarily by student volunteers from the [[University of Ulster]] and [[Queen's University Belfast]]. Volunteers receive training in child mentoring and in child protection policy and procedures.
===Fundraising activities=== YES relies on the goodwill of volunteers in terms of time and also donations to run the charity. Some successful charity fundraisers include 'A night at the movies'.<ref name=MBBBOTCC>{{cite web |url=http://news.ulster.ac.uk/releases/2005/1569.html |title=Movies Bring Big Box-Office To Children’s Charity |date=March 11, 2005 |publisher=University of Ulster}}</ref>
Film fans came together at the Sheridan IMAX movie theatre to raise over £1,500 in box-office takings for a children’s charity.'The silver screen worked its magic for the Youth Empowerment Scheme (YES), a cross community, multi-ethnic charity set up by UU and QUB students to work as mentors with children aged 11–14. Featuring live jazz as well as cinema the special fundraising event - billed as ‘A Night at the Movies’.<ref name=MBBBOTCC />
